questions.answerC: Loads are usually stable.
questions.explanation: Driving with a dry bulk tank requires special care, both because dry bulk tanks have high centers of gravity and because their loads often shift in transit. Be especially careful when taking turns and curves while operating such a vehicle.

questions.question: Scan the road ____ ahead of your vehicle.
questions.answerB: Five to six seconds
questions.answerC: 12 to 15 seconds
questions.explanation: Good drivers scan the road at least 12 to 15 seconds ahead of their vehicles. Looking ahead will allow you to identify and react to hazards before meeting them. Be sure to specifically look for vehicles that are coming onto the highway, entering into your lane, or turning.

questions.question: When driving under wet conditions, a lack of spray coming from the tires of other vehicles indicates that:
questions.answerA: Ice has formed on the road.
questions.answerB: The pavement is dry.
questions.answerC: The spray is caught on the underside of the vehicle.
questions.explanation: In wet conditions, a lack of spray coming from the tires of other vehicles indicates that ice has formed on the road. Be especially cautious when traveling under wet conditions in freezing weather.

questions.question: As part of the vehicle inspection test, a CDL applicant may be asked to:
questions.answerB: Replace a tire.
questions.answerC: Remove the alternator belt.
questions.explanation: When checking the engine compartment during the vehicle inspection test, you will need to check the engine oil level.

questions.question: If a vehicle has air brakes, the air compressor drive belt should be checked before each drive. In what condition should the belt be?
questions.answerB: Tight
questions.answerC: Cracked
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle with air brakes that has a belt-driven air compressor, you should check the condition and tightness of the belt. It should be in good condition.

questions.question: When inspecting the engine compartment, you should not:
questions.answerB: Check the coolant level in the radiator.
questions.answerC: Drain the brake fluid.
questions.answerD: Check the windshield washer fluid level.
questions.explanation: When inspecting the engine compartment, you should check the oil level, coolant level, and windshield washer fluid level, among other things.

questions.question: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to:
questions.answerB: Explain to the examiner what you are inspecting and why.
questions.answerC: Estimate the weight of a load on a trailer.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to do a complete inspection of your vehicle. You will need to explain what you are inspecting and why.

questions.question: When backing, you should:
questions.answerA: Move quickly to get out of other drivers' ways.
questions.answerB: Try not to use the mirrors.
questions.answerC: Use a helper, if possible.
questions.explanation: Driving in reverse is always dangerous because you cannot see everything behind your vehicle. Whenever possible, use a helper to monitor your blind spots.

questions.question: During a trip, gauges are:
questions.answerB: The only way a driver can learn of potential trouble with the vehicle.
questions.answerC: A way to learn of potential trouble with the vehicle.
questions.explanation: During a trip, you should regularly check the gauge and instrument panels, mirrors, tires, cargo, and lights for signs of trouble.

questions.question: Header boards:
questions.answerB: Protect the driver from being hit by cargo.
questions.answerC: Protect the driver's head when entering the cab of a truck.
questions.explanation: Front-end header boards, also known as "headache racks," protect the driver from cargo moving in the event of a crash or emergency stop.

questions.question: If feeling tired and frequently yawning, you should:
questions.answerB: Get some coffee.
questions.answerC: Drive faster.
questions.answerD: Pull over and take a nap.
questions.explanation: Frequent yawning is a warning sign of fatigue. If you become tired while driving, the only safe response is to stop and get some sleep. You cannot rely on artificial stimulants, like caffeine, to keep you alert because they will eventually wear off and leave you more tired than you originally were.

questions.question: When traveling with cargo, the cargo should be checked:
questions.answerB: Before the trip and after the first 50 miles.
questions.answerC: Only by loading personnel.
questions.answerD: Only after arriving to the final destination.
questions.explanation: Cargo should be inspected before beginning a trip, within the first 50 miles of the trip, and every three hours or 150 miles traveled thereafter. The driver of a truck transporting cargo is responsible for the cargo being safely secured throughout the trip.

questions.question: Air tanks usually hold enough compressed air:
questions.answerA: For one stop before needing to be refilled.
questions.answerB: For several stops before needing to be refilled.
questions.answerC: For a day’s worth of braking.
questions.answerD: For an unlimited number of stops.
questions.explanation: In an air braking system, the air storage tanks can usually hold enough compressed air for the brakes to be used several times.

questions.question: During the driving test, the examiner will be scoring you on:
questions.answerB: How quickly you arrive to your destination.
questions.answerC: Your general driving behavior.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, the examiner will be scoring you on specific driving maneuvers, as well as your general driving behavior.

questions.question: To affect a vehicle, ABS:
questions.answerB: Must be on the rear axle.
questions.answerC: Can be on as few as one axle.
questions.explanation: Anti-lock brakes on only a single axle still provides a driver with more control while braking than they would have without any anti-lock brakes.

questions.question: Blocking a load:
questions.answerA: Is only done with liquid cargo.
questions.answerB: Helps to stabilize the load
questions.answerC: Is dangerous and should never be done.
questions.explanation: Blocking and bracing are used to prevent cargo from shifting in transit.

questions.question: If making a tight turn, the operator of a CMV should:
questions.answerA: Be able to drive as fast as the driver of a car.
questions.answerB: Not be concerned about speed, but focus on the road.
questions.answerC: Warn drivers behind by braking early and slowing gradually.
questions.explanation: Drivers behind you may not anticipate how slowly your CMV must travel to safely make a right turn. You can help warn them in advance by braking early and slowing gradually.

questions.question: When conducting a pre-drive inspection:
questions.answerA: The inspection report is not important.
questions.answerB: The inspection report must only be reviewed if there will be passengers in the vehicle.
questions.answerC: The previous inspection report should be reviewed, if applicable.
questions.explanation: The first step of a vehicle inspection is to review the last vehicle inspection report. Only sign the report if noted defects are certified to have been repaired.

questions.question: The parking brake should be:
questions.answerA: Used whenever you park the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Used while driving.
questions.answerC: Set when driving in bad weather.
questions.answerD: Used to stop the vehicle in normal driving.
questions.explanation: The parking brake should be applied every time you park your vehicle.

questions.question: Rough acceleration:
questions.answerA: Is a good way to stay awake on long trips.
questions.answerB: Is distracting.
questions.answerC: Can cause mechanical damage.
questions.answerD: Should be used to prevent rust from forming.
questions.explanation: Always accelerate smoothly and gradually so that your vehicle does not jerk. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: Rims with welding repairs:
questions.answerA: Are not safe to be used.
questions.answerB: Are acceptable to be used on tires on the rear of a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Are acceptable to be used only when carrying a heavy load.
questions.explanation: Wheels or rims that have had welding repairs should never be used.

questions.question: After a vehicle is started, warning lights and buzzers:
questions.answerA: Should stay on for several minutes.
questions.answerB: Should turn off within a few seconds.
questions.answerC: Should stay on until manually turned off.
questions.explanation: After starting the engine, warning lights and buzzers should go out right away. If a light stays on, it usually indicates an issue with the vehicle.

questions.question: If you must drive a school bus during periods of high winds, you should:
questions.answerA: Loosen your grip on the steering wheel.
questions.answerB: Increase your speed.
questions.answerC: Reduce your speed.
questions.explanation: You should slow down when driving a school bus in high winds. Keep a strong grip on the steering wheel and try to anticipate gusts.

questions.question: When exiting your vehicle, you must maintain ____ with the vehicle at all times.
questions.answerB: Four points of contact
questions.answerC: Three points of contact
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: When performing a pre-trip inspection and looking into the fifth wheel gap, you should:
questions.answerA: Make sure the locking jaws are open.
questions.answerB: Make sure the locking jaws are fully closed around the kingpin.
questions.answerC: Make sure the locking jaws are loose.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a trailer coupling, you should make sure the fifth wheel locking jaws are closed around the shank of the kingpin, not the head of the kingpin.

questions.question: Outside mirrors should be adjusted:
questions.answerB: While you are driving.
questions.answerC: After students get on the bus.
questions.explanation: The adjustment of all mirrors on a school bus should always be checked before the bus is driven.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, you may be asked to:
questions.answerB: Parallel park.
questions.answerC: Drive straight into a parking space.
questions.explanation: Maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right parking, offset back/left parking, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: When should you inspect the mirrors on a bus?
questions.answerB: While operating the bus
questions.answerC: After operating the bus
questions.answerD: Is not necessary to inspect the mirrors.
questions.explanation: The mirrors of a bus should always be inspected before a trip. Adjust them as necessary before beginning to drive.

questions.question: An outside convex mirror is properly adjusted if:
questions.answerA: The driver can see at least one lane of traffic and the entire side of the bus.
questions.answerB: The driver can see the front bumper.
questions.answerC: The driver can see the top of the bus.
questions.answerD: The driver can see the front windshield.
questions.explanation: The outside right and left side convex mirrors on a school bus should be positioned so that the driver can see the fronts of the rear tires touching the ground; each side of the bus up to the mirror mounts; and at least one traffic lane on either side of the bus.

questions.question: During the vehicle inspection test, you must be able to do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Show where the power steering fluid dipstick is located.
questions.answerB: Check for adequate power steering fluid.
questions.answerC: Ensure that the power steering fluid level is above the full mark.
questions.explanation: During the pre-trip vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to indicate where the power steering fluid dipstick or reservoir sight glass is located. You will need to show that the power steering fluid is within a safe operating range.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, you may be asked to:
questions.answerB: Inspect your tires.
questions.answerC: Monitor your gauges.
questions.answerD: Pull forward into a parking space.
questions.explanation: Maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right parking, offset back/left parking, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: When boarding the school bus, students should:
questions.answerB: Be in pairs.
questions.answerC: Not use the handrail.
questions.answerD: Try to take two stairs at a time.
questions.explanation: Students should board a school bus slowly in a single-file line while using the handrail.

questions.question: School bus stops may be changed by:
questions.answerB: Parents.
questions.answerC: The school district.
questions.explanation: A school bus driver should not change the location of a stop without written approval from appropriate school district officials.

questions.question: When students board a school bus, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Check all mirrors.
questions.answerC: Only look at the students.
questions.explanation: While students are boarding a school bus, the driver should supervise the loading while watching all mirrors for any students running to catch the bus.

questions.question: If a driver needs to exit a school bus to ensure all the students have boarded, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Turn off the engine and take the key.
questions.answerC: Ask another bus driver to keep an eye on their bus.
questions.answerD: Ask all students to exit the bus.
questions.explanation: While students are boarding a school bus, if the driver cannot account for a student outside, they should secure the bus, take the key with them, and check around and underneath the bus.

questions.question: Properly adjusted outside convex mirrors should allow the driver to see:
questions.answerA: Where the front of each rear tire touches the ground.
questions.answerB: Where the front of each front tire touches the ground.
questions.answerC: The top of the bus.
questions.explanation: On a school bus, outside convex mirrors should be adjusted to allow the driver to see at least one traffic lane on either side of the bus; the entire side of the bus up to the mirror mounts; and where the front of each rear tire touches the ground.

questions.question: Properly adjusted mirrors on a school bus allow the driver to see ____ behind the bus.
questions.answerB: 100 feet
questions.answerC: 200 feet
questions.explanation: Proper mirror adjustment is vital to the safe operation of a school bus. A bus's flat mirrors should be adjusted so the driver is able to see 200 feet, or four bus lengths, behind the bus.

questions.question: When approaching a school bus stop, the bus driver should:
questions.answerB: Approach the stop with caution.
questions.answerC: Stop on the sidewalk.
questions.explanation: A school bus driver should always approach bus stops slowly and cautiously.

questions.question: If a driver cannot account for a student after the student has exited the bus, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Secure and leave the bus to look for the student.
questions.answerB: Assume the student has safely exited the bus.
questions.answerC: Walk to the back of the bus to see if the student got back on.
questions.answerD: Ask another student if they've seen the student.
questions.explanation: During unloading, if a school bus driver cannot account for a student outside of the bus, they should secure the bus and check for the missing student around and underneath the bus.

questions.question: Where are danger zones of a school bus located?
questions.answerA: In the front of the bus
questions.answerB: To the sides of the bus
questions.answerC: To the front, rear, and sides of the bus
questions.explanation: The danger zones of a school bus are areas in which children are most likely to be hit, either by another vehicle or by the bus itself. Such areas are located to the front, sides, and rear of a bus.

questions.question: If a driver needs to exit a school bus to ensure all waiting students have boarded, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Turn the bus off and take the key.
questions.answerC: Ask a student to keep an eye on the steering wheel.
questions.explanation: While students are boarding a school bus, if the driver cannot account for a student outside, they should secure the bus, take the key with them, and check around and underneath the bus for the missing student.

questions.question: When operating a school bus, mirrors should be adjusted:
questions.answerB: Before beginning to drive.
questions.answerC: After the drive is completed.
questions.explanation: It is critical to the safe operation of a school bus that mirrors be properly adjusted. Always check each mirror before operating the bus.

questions.question: The area to the left of a school bus is considered especially dangerous to students because:
questions.answerA: The sun’s reflection obscures the left side of the bus.
questions.answerB: Passing vehicles are located to the left of the bus.
questions.answerC: It is difficult to see the left side of any bus.
questions.answerD: There is no door on the left side of the bus.
questions.explanation: While all sides of a school bus have danger zones, the left side is particularly hazardous to students due to the presence of passing vehicles.

questions.question: School buses:
questions.answerB: Are only equipped with ABS if students who are younger than 10 years of age will be on the bus.
questions.answerC: May be equipped with ABS.
questions.explanation: In general, school buses manufactured after 1998 or 1999 must be equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS). Many older buses are equipped with ABS as well.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, you may be asked to:
questions.answerB: Parallel park to your right.
questions.answerC: Parallel park to your left.
questions.explanation: Maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right parking, offset back/left parking, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: After traveling under an overpass during the driving skills test, you may be asked to recall:
questions.answerB: The posted weight limit.
questions.answerC: The width of the opening.
questions.answerD: If there was a shoulder near the roadway.
questions.explanation: If you drive under an overpass during the on-road driving skills test, your examiner may ask you to recall the posted clearance or height of the overpass.

questions.question: If a school bus stalls on a railroad track:
questions.answerA: Students should remain on the bus.
questions.answerB: Students should be evacuated to a location near the bus.
questions.answerC: Students should be evacuated and moved away from the bus.
questions.explanation: If a school bus becomes stalled or trapped on railroad tracks, the driver should immediately evacuate everyone from the bus. If the bus is struck by a train, to avoid any flying debris, the students should be led far away from the bus at an angle that is in the direction of any oncoming train.

questions.question: The overhead rearview mirror is located:
questions.answerA: On the outside left of the bus.
questions.answerB: On the outside right of the bus.
questions.answerC: Above the windshield inside the bus.
questions.explanation: In a school bus, the overhead rearview mirror is mounted directly above the windshield on the driver’s side.

questions.question: Loading and unloading a bus:
questions.answerB: Does not need to be supervised.
questions.answerC: Should be done while refueling.
questions.explanation: More students are killed each year during loading or unloading of school buses than while riding on school buses. Therefore, it is critical that school bus drivers follow appropriate safety procedures during loading and unloading.

questions.question: An outside convex mirror is properly adjusted if:
questions.answerA: The driver can see at least one lane of traffic and the entire side of the bus.
questions.answerB: The driver can see the front bumper.
questions.answerC: The driver can see the top of the bus.
questions.answerD: The driver can see the front windshield.
questions.explanation: The outside right and left side convex mirrors on a school bus should be positioned so that the driver can see the fronts of the rear tires touching the ground; each side of the bus up to the mirror mounts; and at least one traffic lane on either side of the bus.

questions.question: Students loading and unloading a bus:
questions.answerA: Is simple and does not need to be supervised.
questions.answerB: Can be dangerous and should be supervised.
questions.answerC: May be done without the bus driver present.
questions.explanation: More students are killed each year during loading or unloading of school buses than while riding on school buses. Therefore, it is critical that school bus drivers follow appropriate safety procedures during loading and unloading. This process should never take place without being properly supervised.

questions.question: Backing a school bus is:
questions.answerB: Strongly discouraged.
questions.answerC: Only to be done in the morning.
questions.explanation: Backing a school bus is strongly discouraged and should only be done if there is no safe alternative. If you must drive in reverse, be sure to follow all proper safety protocol.

questions.question: When performing a pre-trip inspection and looking into the fifth wheel gap, you should:
questions.answerA: Make sure there is a gap between the kingpin and the locking jaws.
questions.answerB: Make sure the locking jaws are fully closed around the kingpin.
questions.answerC: Make sure the locking jaws are loose.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a tractor/trailer coupling, look into the fifth wheel gap and make sure the locking jaws are fully closed around the kingpin.

questions.question: As a general rule, student safety is best maintained by:
questions.answerA: Keeping the students on the bus.
questions.answerB: Letting some students evacuate the bus, while others stay on.
questions.answerC: Letting students evacuate the bus.
questions.explanation: In most emergency situations, students will be safest and best kept under control if they do not evacuate the school bus.

questions.question: As students exit the bus, the driver should watch students to ensure that:
questions.answerB: They do not get caught on the handrail or door.
questions.answerC: They do not talk while exiting the bus.
questions.explanation: The driver of a school bus should observe students as they enter or exit the bus to ensure that they are not caught in the door or handrails. It is also important to make sure the students have moved a safe distance away from the unloading area after they have exited the bus.

questions.question: If your bus is equipped with a roof-mounted strobe light, it should be used:
questions.answerB: All the time.
questions.answerC: Only at night.
questions.explanation: If equipped, a school bus's roof-mounted strobe light should be used when conditions create an environment of limited visibility.

questions.question: If a student drops an item while approaching the bus, the student should:
questions.answerA: Stop and pick up the object.
questions.answerB: Have another student pick up the object.
questions.answerC: Ask the driver to pick up the object.
questions.answerD: Just leave the item alone and walk away.
questions.explanation: It is dangerous for students to retrieve dropped items because doing so could cause them to disappear from the driver's view at a crucial moment. If an item is dropped, the student should get out of the bus's danger zones, get the attention of the driver, and ask the driver to retrieve the item.

questions.question: If your bus has a manual transmission, you should never ____ while crossing railroad tracks.
questions.answerB: Use the brakes
questions.answerC: Look both ways
questions.explanation: Before crossing railroad tracks, you should ensure that no trains are approaching from any direction. Never shift gears while crossing railroad tracks.

questions.question: During a vehicle inspection, ensure that lug nuts are all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Free of distortions.
questions.answerC: Loose.
questions.explanation: During a vehicle inspection test, you must ensure that all lug nuts are present, free of cracks and distortions, and showing no signs of looseness, such as rust trails or shiny threads. Verify that all bolt holes are free of cracks and distortions.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, you may be asked to:
questions.answerB: Parallel park.
questions.answerC: Drive straight into a parking space.
questions.explanation: Maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right parking, offset back/left parking, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: When exiting your vehicle, you:
questions.answerA: Must maintain four points of contact with the vehicle.
questions.answerB: May turn to face the road before your exit is complete.
questions.answerC: Must be facing away from the vehicle.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: A properly adjusted flat mirror should allow the driver to see:
questions.answerA: The rear tires touching the ground.
questions.answerB: The front tires touching the ground.
questions.answerC: Only the roadway and no parts of the bus.
questions.explanation: Properly adjusted flat mirrors on a school bus should allow the driver to see 200 feet behind the bus, the base of each rear wheel, and the sides of the bus.

questions.question: Regulations require hazardous materials employees to be trained and tested how often?
questions.answerB: Once every three years
questions.answerC: Once every five years
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials employees must be trained and tested at least once every three years. Drivers must learn the risks associated with hazardous materials and be able to properly respond to security threats.

questions.question: What could indicate that a shipment you are accepting contains hazardous materials?
questions.answerA: The cargo is stored in cylinder tanks.
questions.answerB: The cargo is picked up from a supermarket.
questions.answerC: The cargo is packaged in cardboard boxes.
questions.explanation: Cylinders and drums are often used to contain hazardous materials. Be sure to take the proper precautions if transporting a cargo of hazardous materials.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing while transporting chlorine:
questions.answerA: You must stop before crossing the tracks.
questions.answerB: You must reduce your speed before crossing the tracks.
questions.answerC: You can proceed without stopping if no warning lights are flashing.
questions.answerD: You can proceed without stopping if no other vehicles are within sight.
questions.explanation: If transporting any amount of chlorine, a driver must always stop at a railroad crossing 15 to 50 feet from the nearest track.

questions.question: If transporting a package that contains radioactive materials, it is important to know that:
questions.answerA: Radiation will pass through to other packages.
questions.answerB: The package should be placed in the cab.
questions.answerC: The package should be loaded on its side.
questions.answerD: The package should be made of wood.
questions.explanation: Radiation will surround each package of radioactive materials and pass through to all nearby packages. The number of packages that can be loaded together is controlled.

questions.question: An indicator that cargo contains hazardous materials is:
questions.answerA: The cargo is stored in cylinder tanks.
questions.answerB: The cargo is picked up from a supermarket.
questions.answerC: The cargo is packaged in cardboard boxes.
questions.explanation: Packaging can be an indicator of whether or not materials are hazardous. Cylinders and drums are often used to hold and transport hazardous materials.

questions.question: When a driver is not in their vehicle, hazardous materials' shipping papers should be:
questions.answerB: Kept on the driver’s seat.
questions.answerC: Kept under the passenger’s seat.
questions.explanation: Shipping papers for hazardous materials should always be easily accessible. When a driver is not in their vehicle, hazardous materials' shipping papers should be left on the driver's seat.

questions.question: Identification numbers assigned to chemicals can be found:
questions.answerA: In the DOT Emergency Response Guidebook.
questions.answerB: In the truck's operation manual.
questions.answerC: On the EPA’s website.
questions.explanation: The United States Department of Transportation (DOT)’s Emergency Response Guidebook (ERG) lists all hazardous chemicals and their assigned identification numbers.

questions.question: How long do shippers need to keep a copy of shipping papers for hazardous materials?
questions.answerB: One year
questions.answerC: Two years
questions.explanation: Shippers of hazardous materials must retain a copy or electronic image of the associated shipping papers for at least two years from the date that the material is accepted by the initial carrier. For hazardous waste, this increases to three years.

questions.question: What should be done if the third column of the Hazardous Materials Table contains the word “Forbidden?”
questions.answerA: The indicated substance should not be transported.
questions.answerB: The indicated substance should be transported by air.
questions.answerC: The indicated substance should only be transported at night.
questions.answerD: The indicated substance should be accompanied by a security guard.
questions.explanation: The third column of the Hazardous Materials Table lists items' hazard classes and divisions. Drivers should never transport a material that is marked by the word "Forbidden."

questions.question: When transporting Division 1.1 materials, the floor liner should be:
questions.answerB: Made from an iron alloy.
questions.answerC: Made from non-ferrous materials.
questions.explanation: Use a floor lining when transporting Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 materials. The floors should be tight and the liner must be made from either non-metallic material or non-ferrous metal. Non-ferrous metals are metals that do not contain iron or iron alloys.

questions.question: Shipping papers should be:
questions.answerB: Placed in the glove box.
questions.answerC: Easily seen by anyone entering the cab.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, shipping papers should be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door, or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be easily visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: If a package of hazardous materials is not large enough to hold a label, it should be labeled:
questions.answerB: With a tag.
questions.answerC: By being placed in a certain part of the trailer.
questions.explanation: If a hazardous materials label will not fit onto a package, it may be placed on a tag that is securely attached to the package.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an acceptable location to keep hazardous materials' shipping papers?
questions.answerA: In a pouch on the driver’s side door
questions.answerB: In a pouch on the passenger’s side door
questions.answerC: Within reach of the driver while the seat belt is fastened
questions.answerD: On the driver’s seat while the driver is outside of the vehicle
questions.explanation: When the vehicle is being driven, hazardous materials' shipping papers must be kept in a pouch on the driver's door or somewhere else that is in clear view and within the driver's reach. If the driver is outside of the vehicle, the shipping papers should be kept on the driver's seat.

questions.question: If you apply for a HazMat endorsement, you must undergo a check through which agency?
questions.answerB: The Federal Bureau of Investigation
questions.answerC: The Department of Energy
questions.explanation: To obtain an original or renewed hazardous materials endorsement, you must pass a Transportation Security Administration (TSA) background check.

questions.question: When loading or unloading explosive materials, you should:
questions.answerB: Turn off the engine.
questions.answerC: Use sharp-pointed tools to open the packages.
questions.explanation: Always turn off your vehicle's engine before loading or unloading explosive materials. Never drop, throw, or roll packages containing explosives.

questions.question: Placarded vehicles must carry fire extinguishers with a minimum rating of:
questions.explanation: The power unit of a placarded vehicle must be equipped with a fire extinguisher with an Underwriters Laboratories (UL) rating of 10 B:C or more.

questions.question: An explosive material is most likely categorized as a ____ hazard.
questions.answerB: Class 3
questions.answerC: Class 6
questions.explanation: Class 1 hazardous materials are typically items that present certain explosion or fire hazards.

questions.question: Hazardous materials shipping papers must include:
questions.answerB: The price of the materials.
questions.answerC: The intended use of the materials.
questions.answerD: The country of origin of the materials.
questions.explanation: Drivers must be aware of the risks associated with materials they are transporting. Hazardous materials shipping papers must include an emergency response telephone number.

questions.question: How often do hazardous materials employees need to be trained?
questions.answerB: At least once every three years
questions.answerC: At least one every 10 years
questions.explanation: Employees who work with hazardous materials must be trained and tested at least once every three years.

questions.question: If a driver stops and leaves their vehicle while transporting hazardous materials, the shipping papers should be:
questions.answerB: Left in the front seat of the cab.
questions.answerC: Placed in a box under the passenger seat.
questions.explanation: If a driver stops and exits their vehicle, the hazardous materials shipping papers must be left on the driver's seat.

questions.question: A placard should be placed:
questions.answerA: At least three inches away from any other markings.
questions.answerB: Under a ladder, if space is an issue.
questions.answerC: On a background that is a similar color to the placard.
questions.explanation: A placard must be placed at least three inches away from any other markings. The placard should be kept clear of attachments or devices, such as doors and ladders. Placards should always be placed against a background of a contrasting color.

questions.question: How many identical placards must be placed on a vehicle?
questions.answerB: Two
questions.answerC: Four
questions.explanation: A placarded vehicle must have at least four identical placards: one on the front, one on the rear, and one on each side of the vehicle.

questions.question: Shippers package in order to ____ hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Release
questions.answerC: Insulate
questions.explanation: Shippers package hazardous materials in a way that is meant to completely contain the materials. Vehicles should be placarded to communicate the risk of the cargo.

questions.question: If a shipping paper describes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials may need to be:
questions.answerB: Circled by a pen or marker.
questions.answerC: Unmarked.
questions.explanation: If a shipping paper describes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials must be distinguished in one of three ways. They must be entered first on the shipping paper, highlighted in a contrasting color, or properly marked with an "X" in a column titled "HM."

questions.question: If a substance is transported in a reportable quantity, which letters must appear on the shipping paper and package?
questions.answerB: LT
questions.answerC: RQ
questions.explanation: When hazardous materials are being transported in a reportable quantity in one package, the shipper must display the letters "RQ" on the shipping paper and package.

questions.question: If a package of explosives has an oily stain or shows dampness, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Decline transporting the load.
questions.answerC: Use towels to absorb the liquid.
questions.explanation: You should never transport damaged packages of explosives. Do not accept a package that seems damp or has an oily stain.

questions.question: If hazardous materials are being transported, how are other drivers warned?
questions.answerA: By the posting of placards on the truck
questions.answerB: By the flashing lights on the truck
questions.answerC: By a siren
questions.answerD: By the driver waving an arm out the window
questions.explanation: Diamond-shaped signs called placards are placed on the outside of vehicles carrying hazardous materials to alert other drivers to the presence of the materials.

questions.question: When placing a placard:
questions.answerA: It should be at least three inches away from any other markings.
questions.answerB: It could be placed under a ladder if space is an issue.
questions.answerC: It can be affixed to a background of similar color.
questions.explanation: Among other requirements, hazardous materials placards must be placed at least three inches away from any other markings; away from ladders or other attachments or devices; on backgrounds of contrasting color; and upright, with words or numbers level and reading left to right.

questions.question: In the event of a fire, what should you do before opening trailer doors?
questions.answerA: Check to see if the doors are hot.
questions.answerB: Throw water on the doors.
questions.answerC: Find someone else to open the doors.
questions.explanation: If you are experiencing a truck fire, you should not attempt to open trailer doors without first feeling the doors to see if they are hot. If the doors are hot, there may be a cargo fire. In this case, leave the doors closed because opening the doors could worsen the fire by supplying it with more oxygen.

questions.question: In the event of a cargo fire, opening trailer doors may cause a fire to expand because:
questions.answerA: Oxygen will be allowed into the area.
questions.answerB: The temperature of the trailer will change.
questions.answerC: It will provide moisture.
questions.explanation: In the event of a cargo fire, you should not open the trailer doors. Doing this could cause the fire to flare up by giving it access to more oxygen.

questions.question: When loading or unloading explosive materials, you should:
questions.answerB: Turn off the engine.
questions.answerC: Use sharp-pointed tools to open the packages.
questions.explanation: Always turn off your vehicle's engine before loading or unloading explosive materials. Never drop, throw, or roll packages containing explosives.

questions.question: Shipping papers must include:
questions.answerB: The price of the materials.
questions.answerC: The use of the materials.
questions.explanation: Shippers of hazardous materials are required to include an emergency response telephone number on shipping papers.

questions.question: A driver should ensure that:
questions.answerA: The shipping paper matches the markings and labels on packages.
questions.answerB: The shipping paper is written in code.
questions.answerC: All packages are labeled as poison.
questions.explanation: It is always a good idea to compare package markings and labels to accompanying shipping papers. Always make sure the shipper has displayed the correct basic description on the shipping paper and has provided the proper labels on the packages.

questions.question: What does a material’s hazard class reflect?
questions.answerA: The risks associated with the material
questions.answerB: How quickly the material must reach its destination
questions.answerC: How much the material weighs
questions.answerD: The country of origin of the materials
questions.explanation: A hazardous material will fall into one of nine hazard classes. The material's hazard class reflects its associated risks.

questions.question: Shipping papers should be:
questions.answerB: Placed in the glove box.
questions.answerC: Easily seen by anyone entering the cab.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, shipping papers should be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door, or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be easily visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: In addition to reading the manual, what is an effective way to learn about transporting hazardous materials?
questions.answerB: Attending hazardous materials training courses
questions.answerC: Guessing
questions.explanation: While the manual contains all of the information needed to pass the written exam for a hazardous materials endorsement, it does not contain all of the information necessary to do the job safely. You can learn more by attending hazardous materials training courses.

questions.question: If a package of hazardous materials is not large enough to hold a label, it should be labeled:
questions.answerB: With a tag.
questions.answerC: By being placed in a certain part of the trailer.
questions.explanation: If a hazardous materials label will not fit onto a package, it may be placed on a tag that is securely attached to the package.

questions.question: What does "RQ" stand for?
questions.answerB: Reportable quantity
questions.answerC: Release query
questions.explanation: When marking hazardous materials in an "HM" column on a shipping paper, the letters "RQ" may be used instead of an "X" if a reportable quantity of the material must be identified.

questions.question: If you notice a cargo leak, you can identify the leaking cargo:
questions.answerB: By touching it.
questions.answerC: By using the shipping papers.
questions.answerD: By rubbing it on your arm.
questions.explanation: In the event of a leak in a cargo of hazardous materials, use the shipping papers, labels, or package locations to identify the materials involved. Do not touch the leaking materials.

questions.question: A material’s hazard class reflects:
questions.answerA: The risks associated with the material.
questions.answerB: How quickly the material must reach its destination.
questions.answerC: How much the material weighs.
questions.explanation: A hazardous material will be placed into one of nine classes to explain the type of risks associated with the material.

questions.question: On a shipping paper, if the letter “G” appears in Column 1, what else needs to appear?
questions.answerA: The technical name of the hazardous material
questions.answerB: The type of packaging containing the hazardous material
questions.answerC: The shipper’s phone number
questions.answerD: The date the product was packed
questions.explanation: If the letter “G,” for "Generic," is written in Column 1 of a shipping paper, the technical name of the associated hazardous material must also be listed.

questions.question: Portable tanks:
questions.answerA: Cannot be removed from a vehicle.
questions.answerB: Are not permanently attached to a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Are permanently attached to a vehicle.
questions.explanation: Cargo tanks remain on a vehicle at all times, regardless of whether or not they are carrying cargo. Portable tanks are bulk packaging and are not permanently attached to a vehicle.

questions.question: If transporting chlorine, what must be in the vehicle?
questions.answerB: Goggles
questions.answerC: An axe
questions.explanation: If transporting chlorine in cargo tanks, a driver must have an approved gas mask in their vehicle.

questions.question: How often are hazardous materials employees required to be trained and tested?
questions.answerB: Once every three years
questions.answerC: Once every five years
questions.explanation: All drivers must be trained in the security risks of hazardous materials transportation. This training must include how to recognize and respond to possible security threats. Hazardous materials employees must be trained and tested at least once every three years.

questions.question: Shipping papers:
questions.answerA: Are not needed for most shipments.
questions.answerB: Are required for all shipments.
questions.answerC: Should be stored in a special compartment in the cab.
questions.answerD: Can be kept as a digital file.
questions.explanation: For all shipments of hazardous materials, the shipper must use shipping papers to inform drivers and dockworkers of the risks presented by the cargo.

questions.question: To determine which placard(s) you must use when carrying hazardous materials, you need to know:
questions.answerA: The hazard classes of the materials.
questions.answerB: The types of containers being used.
questions.answerC: The destination.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials placards are placed on the outside of a vehicle to identify the hazard classes of materials being carried.

questions.question: To distinguish between hazardous and non-hazardous materials on a shipping paper:
questions.answerA: The hazardous materials should be listed at the bottom of the paper.
questions.answerB: The hazardous materials should be listed at the top of the paper.
questions.answerC: The hazardous materials should be highlighted in the same color as the non-hazardous materials.
questions.answerD: The non-hazardous materials should be marked with an "X."
questions.explanation: If a shipping paper includes information about both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials must be differentiated in one of three ways. They must be listed first, highlighted in a contrasting color, or identified with an "X" placed before the shipping description in a column labeled "HM."

questions.question: Hazardous materials shipping papers may not be kept:
questions.answerA: In a pouch on the driver’s door.
questions.answerB: In a pouch on the passenger’s side door.
questions.answerC: Within reach of the driver while the seat belt is fastened.
questions.explanation: Shipping papers must be quickly accessible in the event of an emergency. While driving, operators must keep the papers in a pouch on the driver’s door or in clear view and within immediate reach while their seat belt is fastened. Shipping papers may be kept on the driver’s seat when the driver is out of the vehicle.

questions.question: Shipping papers should be:
questions.answerB: Placed in the glove box.
questions.answerC: Easily seen by anyone entering the cab.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, shipping papers should be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door, or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be easily visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: A person should not smoke within ____ of a vehicle placarded for Class 3 or Division 2.1 materials.
questions.answerB: 25 feet
questions.answerC: 100 feet
questions.explanation: A person should not smoke within 25 feet of a placarded tank that is used to transport Class 3 (flammable liquids) or Division 2.1 (gases) materials. Additionally, no person should smoke or carry a lit cigar, cigarette, or pipe within 25 feet of any vehicle containing Class 1 (explosives), Class 4 (flammable solids), or Class 4.2 (spontaneously combustible).

questions.question: During a cargo fire, opening the trailer doors may actually cause the fire to expand because doing so:
questions.answerB: Changes the temperature of the trailer.
questions.answerC: Provides more moisture to the trailer.
questions.explanation: When experiencing a cargo fire, it may be a bad idea to open the doors to the trailer. Doing so allows oxygen to enter the area, potentially causing the fire to flare up and expand.

questions.question: How do you label a hazardous material if the proper label will not fit on the material's package?
questions.answerA: The label may be placed on a tag securely attached to the package.
questions.answerB: A scannable QR code may instead be attached to the package.
questions.answerC: The HazMat label should be reduced in size to fit on the package.
questions.answerD: The label may be pasted to the wall of the trailer.
questions.explanation: If a hazardous materials label will not fit on a package, it may be placed on a tag that is securely attached to the package.

questions.question: When refueling a vehicle carrying hazardous materials:
questions.answerA: The engine should be left on.
questions.answerB: The engine should be turned off.
questions.answerC: The gas nozzle may be left unattended.
questions.explanation: If you need to refuel a vehicle carrying hazardous materials, you must first turn off the engine. While refueling, someone must be at the nozzle and controlling the fuel flow at all times.

questions.question: If a substance is transported in a reportable quantity, which letters must appear on the shipping paper and package?
questions.answerB: LT
questions.answerC: RQ
questions.explanation: When hazardous materials are being transported in a reportable quantity in one package, the shipper must display the letters "RQ" on the shipping paper and package.

questions.question: A person who is watching the loading or unloading of a tank must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Remain within 25 feet of the tank.
questions.answerC: Wear a chemical suit.
questions.answerD: Know the hazards of the materials involved.
questions.explanation: The person in charge of loading or unloading a hazardous materials cargo tank must ensure that a qualified person is always supervising the process. The supervisor must be alert; have a clear view of the tank; be within 25 feet of the tank; know the hazards of the involved materials; know the procedures to follow in the case of an emergency; and be authorized to and capable of moving the tank.

questions.question: When driving a vehicle with empty cargo tanks that are used to transport hazardous materials, a driver:
questions.answerA: Should not cross a railroad crossing.
questions.answerB: Needs to slow when approaching a railroad crossing, but is not required to stop.
questions.answerC: Must stop at a railroad crossing.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle has cargo tanks that are used to carry hazardous materials, you must stop before crossing railroad tracks. This is true whether the tanks are full or empty.

questions.question: On packages that are not large enough to hold a HazMat label, materials should be labeled:
questions.answerB: With a tag.
questions.answerC: With a piece of orange tape.
questions.explanation: If a package of hazardous materials is not large enough to display the proper label, the label may be placed on a tag that is securely attached to the package.

questions.question: If you are transporting hazardous materials and the cargo is on fire, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to put it out with a fire extinguisher.
questions.answerB: Contact emergency personnel and let them battle the fire.
questions.answerC: Hope the fire goes out by itself.
questions.explanation: Fighting a hazardous materials fire requires special training and protective gear. Unless you have the proper equipment and training, do not try to fight a hazardous materials fire yourself.

questions.question: If transporting chlorine, what must be in the vehicle?
questions.answerB: Goggles
questions.answerC: An axe
questions.explanation: A driver transporting chlorine in cargo tanks must have an approved gas mask in the vehicle, as well as an emergency kit for controlling leaks in dome cover plate fittings on the cargo tank.

questions.question: Emergency response information provided by the shipper must include:
questions.answerB: Value of the materials.
questions.answerC: Date of packing.
questions.explanation: At a minimum, emergency response information must include the basic descriptions and technical names of the materials being transported; immediate hazards to health; risks of fire or explosion; immediate precautions to be taken in the event of an accident or incident; immediate methods for handling fires; initial methods for handling spills or leaks in the absence of fires; and preliminary first aid measures.

questions.question: You must have an air brake endorsement:
questions.answerA: To use a vehicle with air brakes.
questions.answerB: To drive any truck with a trailer.
questions.answerC: To transport hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: You must take an air brakes knowledge test to become licensed to operate a vehicle that is equipped with air brakes, including an air over hydraulic braking system.

questions.question: What can rust around the wheel nuts indicate?
questions.answerB: That the nuts are wet.
questions.answerC: That the nuts need to be replaced.
questions.answerD: That the nuts are the wrong size.
questions.explanation: Rust around wheel nuts can indicate that they are loose. If you observe rust, check the tightness of the nuts.

questions.question: If turning to avoid a hazard:
questions.answerB: You should not brake as it could cause the wheels to lock.
questions.answerC: You should turn the wheel very sharply.
questions.answerD: You should hold down the brakes until you are past the hazard.
questions.explanation: If you are turning to avoid a hazard, do not apply the brakes while you are turning. This could easily lock the wheels and create a skid.

questions.question: Poisonous fumes can enter the cab due to:
questions.answerB: The wrong type of fuel being used.
questions.answerC: A lack of oil in the engine.
questions.explanation: Defects in an exhaust system are very dangerous because they can cause poisonous fumes to enter the cab or sleeper berth.

questions.question: When trying to avoid a hazard:
questions.answerB: Swerving may be more effective than stopping.
questions.answerC: You may change lanes without looking.
questions.answerD: You should drive on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: Stopping is not always the most effective response to a hazard. You can usually turn out of the path of a hazard more quickly than you can come to a complete stop. However, swerving is not without its hazards, as it may result in a rollover in a vehicle that is either top-heavy or pulling multiple trailers.

questions.question: If coolant has to be added to a system without a recovery tank, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep the vehicle running while adding coolant.
questions.answerB: Open the radiator cap quickly.
questions.answerC: Not use gloves to touch the radiator cap.
questions.answerD: Wait for the engine to cool before adding coolant.
questions.explanation: Before adding coolant to a system without a recovery or overflow tank, you must turn the engine off and wait until it cools. Use gloves or a thick cloth to protect your hands. To release the pressure seal, turn the radiator cap slowly to the first stop.

questions.question: When completing pre-trip inspections:
questions.answerA: The inspections should be done the same way each time.
questions.answerB: Different items should be checked each time.
questions.answerC: It is acceptable to check items in a different order each time.
questions.answerD: Not every item needs to be inspected each time.
questions.explanation: Pre-trip inspections should be conducted in the same way every time. This will reinforce the steps, making it less likely that you will forget to inspect something important.

questions.question: When should you slow for a curve?
questions.answerB: While in the curve
questions.answerC: After the curve
questions.explanation: You should always slow to a safe speed before entering a curve. Slowing while within the curve could cause a skid.

questions.question: Coupling can be tested by a driver:
questions.answerA: Placing their fingers inside the coupling mechanism.
questions.answerB: Pulling against the pin of the second semi-trailer.
questions.answerC: Placing glue over the fifth wheel.
questions.answerD: Releasing the orange lever in the cab.
questions.explanation: It is essential to safety that a driver inspects coupling before starting a trip. Trailer coupling on a double or triple combination can be tested by pulling against the pin of the second semi-trailer.

questions.question: When a brake pedal is pressed and the S-cam is turned, the S-cam:
questions.answerA: Presses the brake shoes against the inside of the brake drum.
questions.answerB: Tightens the brake drum onto the axle.
questions.answerC: Presses the brake lining against the wheel.
questions.answerD: Releases air from the air tanks.
questions.explanation: When a brake pedal is pressed and the S-cam is turned, the S-cam presses the brake shoes against the inside of the brake drum. This causes friction and will cause the vehicle to slow.

questions.question: If a vehicle is power steering-equipped, the hoses should be:
questions.answerB: Securely connected to the battery.
questions.answerC: Carrying fuel.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle equipped with power steering, you should inspect the hoses, pumps, and fluid levels. Specifically check the hoses for leaks.

questions.question: Driving at night is usually:
questions.answerA: More difficult than driving during the day.
questions.answerB: Simpler than driving during the day.
questions.answerC: Discouraged.
questions.explanation: There are several reasons why driving at night is more difficult than driving during the day. It is more difficult for drivers to see hazards, the glare of headlights can affect drivers' vision, and there are more fatigued drivers on the road.

questions.question: If you realize you may be running late to your destination, you should:
questions.answerB: Get upset.
questions.answerC: Deal with it and drive at a safe speed.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of developing aggressive driving behavior, you should take measures to manage your stress. One strategy to do this is to simply take a deep breath and accept your circumstances if you realize you will be late to your destination.

questions.question: To ensure that you do not slow down traffic when driving a large truck, you should:
questions.answerB: Try to pass another vehicle while driving uphill.
questions.answerC: Stay in the right lane whenever possible.
questions.explanation: If a heavy load prevents your vehicle from keeping up with the speed of other traffic, you should stay in the right lane.

questions.question: A truck should be parked:
questions.answerA: So that it must be backed up to leave the space.
questions.answerB: So that it can be pulled forward to leave the space.
questions.answerC: On the grass.
questions.explanation: Because you can't see everything behind you, backing is always dangerous and should be avoided whenever possible. Choose parking spaces from which you can pull forward when you leave.

questions.question: If you realize you may be running late to your destination, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive while using flashing lights so other road users move out of your path.
questions.answerC: Drive at a safe speed and arrive when you arrive.
questions.explanation: To avoid engaging in dangerous and aggressive driving behavior, you should relax and accept any delays that arise throughout a trip. To help avoid the stress of arriving late to a destination, plan for likely delays when planning your drive.

questions.question: Retreaded tires:
questions.answerA: May be used on any part of a bus.
questions.answerB: May be used on the front of a bus.
questions.answerC: May be used on the rear of a bus.
questions.answerD: May never be used on a bus.
questions.explanation: Regrooved, recapped, or retreaded tires are prohibited from use on the front wheels of a bus.

questions.question: What is the Johnson bar?
questions.answerA: A hand valve that works the trailer brakes
questions.answerB: A valve that indicates the fuel level
questions.answerC: A valve that measures the amount of liquid in the air brake system
questions.answerD: A valve that allows for the release of excess pressure in the braking system
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve, also called the trolley valve or Johnson bar, is used to work the trailer brakes. It should be used only to test the brakes.

questions.question: During a walk-around inspection, ensure the release arm is properly seated and the safety latch or lock is:
questions.answerB: Deactivated.
questions.answerC: Polished.
questions.explanation: When inspecting the fifth wheel before a trip, you should ensure that the release arm is properly seated and the safety latch or lock is engaged. All components should be present and in proper working condition.

questions.question: Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS):
questions.answerA: Reduce a vehicle's normal braking capacity.
questions.answerB: Are in addition to other braking systems and do not reduce a vehicle's braking power.
questions.answerC: Are not effective on larger vehicles.
questions.explanation: If equipped, ABS is in addition to a vehicle's normal braking system and does not increase or decrease the braking power of any other system. ABS only activates when a vehicle's wheels are about to lock.

questions.question: Off-ramps:
questions.answerB: Can be dangerous for trucks.
questions.answerC: Should not be used by trucks.
questions.explanation: On- and off-ramps can be dangerous when driving a truck. Remember that posted speed limits for ramps may be safe for cars but too fast for trucks.

questions.question: When traveling at speeds under 40 mph, you should maintain at least ____ of following distance for every 10 feet of your vehicle's length.
questions.answerB: Two seconds
questions.answerC: Three seconds
questions.explanation: When traveling at speeds under 40 mph, you should allow a minimum of one second of following distance for every 10 feet of your vehicle's length. At faster speeds, add at least one additional second.

questions.question: When driving:
questions.answerA: It is best to hide your intentions from others.
questions.answerB: You should only use turn signals if there are vehicles near you.
questions.answerC: You should not use turn signals in construction zones.
questions.answerD: You should always use turn signals to warn others about your intentions.
questions.explanation: It is important to communicate your intentions to others on the road. Make sure to signal before turning or changing lanes, even if no other vehicles are nearby.

questions.question: If there is a cargo fire in a box trailer:
questions.answerA: The trailer doors should be opened.
questions.answerB: The trailer doors should not be opened.
questions.answerC: A large, heavy blanket should be put over the trailer.
questions.explanation: The doors of a trailer should be not be opened in the event of a cargo fire, especially if the cargo includes hazardous materials. Opening trailer doors would increase the fire's oxygen supply, potentially causing the fire to increase in size.

questions.question: When driving a vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), brakes should be applied:
questions.answerA: In the same way as they would be in a vehicle without ABS.
questions.answerB: As the vehicle is placed in neutral.
questions.answerC: With the hand brake.
questions.explanation: When driving a vehicle with ABS, you should brake in the same manner as you would in a vehicle without ABS.

questions.question: A driver should always:
questions.answerB: Have an emergency plan.
questions.answerC: Stay in the left lane.
questions.explanation: While driving, you should continually scan the road ahead to spot potential hazards well in advance. Make emergency plans for how to deal with the hazards in the event that they become dangerous.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a problem?
questions.answerB: Loose or broken mounting brackets
questions.answerC: Exhaust parts rubbing against fuel system parts
questions.answerD: Exhaust system parts that are not leaking
questions.explanation: When inspecting an exhaust system, you should verify that parts of the system are not loose, broken, or missing. The system's parts must be properly mounted and should not be rubbing against moving parts of the vehicle.

questions.question: Antifreeze helps to keep an engine functioning properly:
questions.answerB: But only in hot weather.
questions.answerC: Regardless of the weather.
questions.answerD: While minimizing the vehicle's fuel use.
questions.explanation: It is always important to have enough water and antifreeze in a vehicle's cooling system. Despite the name, antifreeze is beneficial to an engine even in hot weather.

questions.question: If using a helper when backing a vehicle, the helper should be located:
questions.answerA: In front of the passenger's side of the vehicle.
questions.answerB: In front of the driver's side of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Near the back of the truck.
questions.explanation: When backing up, it is always a good idea for a driver to use a helper who can watch the vehicle's blind spots. The helper should stand near the back of the vehicle in a location where they are visible to the driver.

questions.question: Distracted driving:
questions.answerA: Can be avoided by eating while driving.
questions.answerB: Can be increased by pre-programming radio stations.
questions.answerC: Can be avoided by not engaging in complex conversations with others.
questions.explanation: Distractions while driving can be physical (such as reaching for an object), mental (such as making conversation with a passenger), or both (such as holding a phone to send texts). Strategies to help you avoid distracted driving include pre-programming radio stations; planning out your route in advance; avoiding complex or emotionally taxing conversation while driving; adjusting your mirrors before setting out; and not eating, drinking, or smoking while behind the wheel.

questions.question: Within 10 minutes of stopping on the side of the road, you must:
questions.answerB: Alert local law enforcement.
questions.answerC: Call a mechanic.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the side of the road, you must place the appropriate emergency warning devices within 10 minutes of stopping.

questions.question: If oil and water build up in your vehicle's air tanks, the brakes:
questions.answerB: May feel squishy.
questions.answerC: Will squeal loudly when used.
questions.explanation: Air tanks should be drained daily to remove water and oil buildup. An excess of oil and water in the air tanks can interfere with proper brake function.

questions.question: Braking mechanisms are located inside:
questions.answerB: A brake drum.
questions.answerC: The landing gear.
questions.explanation: Drum brakes are attached to the wheels and located on the axles of a vehicle. The braking mechanisms that cause the vehicle to stop can be found inside of a drum brake.

questions.question: In extremely hot conditions, you may have to:
questions.answerA: Increase your speed to cool the engine.
questions.answerB: Reduce your speed to prevent overheating.
questions.answerC: Drain the engine coolant.
questions.answerD: Follow other vehicles more closely than normal.
questions.explanation: Faster speeds create more heat in the engine and tires, so slow down to avoid dangerous overheating when the weather is very hot.

questions.question: When stopping:
questions.answerA: The brake pedal should be pressed down gradually.
questions.answerB: The brake pedal should be pushed down quickly.
questions.answerC: The brake pedal should be pressed down repeatedly, but not held down continuously.
questions.answerD: The amount of force required on the brake pedal will be the same each time you slow or stop.
questions.explanation: Press the brake pedal down smoothly and gradually every time you slow or stop. The amount of brake pressure you need to apply depends on the speed of your vehicle and how quickly you need to stop.

questions.question: When driving a vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should:
questions.answerA: Stop harder than you would in a vehicle not equipped with ABS.
questions.answerB: Use extra braking force to ensure the ABS kicks in.
questions.answerC: Brake as you would in a vehicle not equipped with ABS.
questions.answerD: Brake with less force than you would in a vehicle not equipped with ABS.
questions.explanation: When driving a tractor-trailer combination that is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should brake in the same manner that you would if the vehicle was not equipped with ABS.

questions.question: When driving in the winter, which of the following should receive extra attention in a pre-trip inspection?
questions.answerB: The air conditioning unit
questions.answerC: Oil levels
questions.explanation: When driving during the winter, it is especially important to make sure the coolant and antifreeze are at safe levels.

questions.question: What is a tractor protection valve?
questions.answerA: A valve to keep air in the brake system should there be a bad leak
questions.answerB: A valve that prevents a truck from being stolen
questions.answerC: A valve that prevents the driver from driving too fast
questions.explanation: A tractor protection valve keeps air in a tractor or truck air brake system should the trailer break away or develop a bad leak. The valve will close automatically if the pressure drops to an unsafe level.

questions.question: What should you do if your vehicle gets stuck on railroad tracks?
questions.answerB: Get out of the vehicle and call for assistance.
questions.answerC: Continue trying to get your vehicle off the tracks until you are successful.
questions.explanation: If your CMV gets stuck on railroad tracks, you should immediately leave the vehicle and get away from the tracks. Check the signposts or signal housing at the crossing for emergency contact information and call 911, or another appropriate emergency number.

questions.question: An air supply control in its "emergency" position will:
questions.answerB: Apply the trailer emergency brakes.
questions.answerC: Prevent a skid.
questions.explanation: Tractor protection controls in older vehicles may be operated by levers instead of knobs. If an air supply control is set in its "emergency" position, the air supply will be stopped and the trailer emergency brakes will be applied.

questions.question: Most heavy vehicles use the ____ method when changing gears.
questions.answerB: Double shifting
questions.answerC: Triple clutching
questions.explanation: Most heavy vehicles with unsynchronized manual transmissions require double clutching to change gears.

questions.question: When approaching a vehicle for a pre-trip inspection, a driver should look under the vehicle:
questions.answerA: To see if the vehicle is on an incline.
questions.answerB: To see if there are any fresh fluids under the vehicle.
questions.answerC: To see if the vehicle is in a parking spot.
questions.answerD: To see if the vehicle is on a decline.
questions.explanation: When approaching your vehicle to conduct an inspection, you should look underneath it to make sure there are no fresh oil, coolant, grease, or fuel leaks on the ground. Leaks can indicate unsafe defects on a vehicle.

questions.question: When a tire goes flat, you may hear a loud bang. The truck will be affected:
questions.answerB: After a short delay.
questions.answerC: Only if the damaged tire is near the front of the truck.
questions.answerD: Only if the truck is hauling a load.
questions.explanation: There may be a delay of a few seconds between the sound of a tire failing and the time that the vehicle is affected by the tire failure. Because of the short delay, a driver may initially believe that the sound came from another vehicle.

questions.question: How should you brake if your vehicle's ABS is not working?
questions.answerA: Brake normally, as you will still have functioning brakes.
questions.answerB: Pump the brake repeatedly.
questions.answerC: Press the brake pedal down as hard as you can.
questions.explanation: Without a working Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), your vehicle will still have normal brake function. Continue to drive and brake as you normally would and have your ABS serviced as soon as possible.

questions.question: When trying to control a minor truck fire, what should you do before opening trailer doors?
questions.answerA: Check to see if the doors are hot.
questions.answerB: Throw water on the doors.
questions.answerC: Remove your protective equipment.
questions.explanation: If you are experiencing a truck fire, you should not attempt to open trailer doors without first feeling the doors to see if they are hot. If the doors are hot, there may be a cargo fire. Leave the doors closed if there is a cargo fire.

questions.question: When driving with a tank, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Make sudden stops.
questions.answerC: Swerve periodically.
questions.explanation: Sudden stops can produce dangerous surge in a tank carrying liquid cargo. To reduce the need for sudden stops, drivers of tanks should increase their following distance so they can begin braking well in advance of stops.

questions.question: Class 1, Class 2.1, and Class 3 items should not be placed in a trailer with:
questions.answerB: An air conditioner.
questions.answerC: Other items.
questions.explanation: The use of cargo heaters is not always permitted. When transporting materials that are categorized as Class 1 (Explosives), Class 2.1 (Flammable Gas), or Class 3 (Flammable Liquids) materials, heaters are generally prohibited.

questions.question: Rollovers happen when:
questions.answerB: You are stopped.
questions.answerC: You turn too quickly.
questions.explanation: Rollovers happen as a result of drivers taking turns too fast.

questions.question: Distracted driving:
questions.answerB: Only occurs as a result of people who are physically doing something while driving.
questions.answerC: Can occur as a result of mental activities, such as daydreaming.
questions.explanation: Distractions while driving can be physical (such as reaching for an object), mental (such as making conversation with a passenger), or both (such as holding a phone to send texts). Strategies to help you avoid distracted driving include pre-programming radio stations; planning out your route in advance; avoiding complex or emotionally taxing conversation while driving; adjusting your mirrors before setting out; and not eating, drinking, or smoking while behind the wheel.

questions.question: How often are hazardous materials employees required to be trained and tested?
questions.answerB: Once every three years
questions.answerC: Once every five years
questions.explanation: All drivers must be trained in the security risks of hazardous materials transportation. This training must include how to recognize and respond to possible security threats. Hazardous materials employees must be trained and tested at least once every three years.

questions.question: When traveling down a downgrade, the speed of a vehicle will likely:
questions.answerB: Not change.
questions.answerC: Increase.
questions.explanation: On a downgrade, the force of gravity will cause a vehicle's speed to increase. When approaching a downgrade, choose to travel at a speed that will be safe for the size and weight of your vehicle.

questions.question: Before driving a tank, you should:
questions.answerA: Check pipes, connections, and hoses for leaks.
questions.answerB: Make sure manhole covers do not have gaskets.
questions.answerC: Ensure all valves are open.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a tank vehicle, it is most important to check for leaks. Check all pipes, connections, and hoses, especially around joints. Make sure manhole covers have gaskets and that they close correctly.

questions.question: What does the vehicle inspection report do?
questions.answerA: Inform the motor carrier about problems that may need fixing
questions.answerB: Ensure that the vehicle is inspected regularly
questions.answerC: Keep people accountable for inspecting the vehicle
questions.explanation: A vehicle inspection report keeps the carrier informed about any problems that need to be fixed.

questions.question: If you are transporting hazardous materials and the cargo is on fire, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to put it out with a fire extinguisher.
questions.answerB: Contact emergency personnel and let them battle the fire.
questions.answerC: Hope the fire goes out by itself.
questions.explanation: Fighting a hazardous materials fire requires special training and protective gear. Unless you have the proper equipment and training, do not try to fight a hazardous materials fire yourself.

questions.question: When are people usually the least alert?
questions.answerB: In the early evening
questions.answerC: Late at night
questions.explanation: Most drivers are the least alert at night, especially after midnight. Therefore, crashes due to fatigued driving are more likely at night than any other time of day.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Make eye contact with the other driver.
questions.answerB: Assume the other driver doesn’t see you.
questions.answerC: Honk your horn.
questions.explanation: It is always safest to assume that other drivers, bicyclists, and pedestrians don't see you. Be prepared for the possibility that they may suddenly move into your path. It may be safe to lightly tap your horn or flash your lights as you pass.

questions.question: When a vehicle is started, the coolant temperature should:
questions.answerB: Rise slowly.
questions.answerC: Jump quickly.
questions.explanation: After an engine is started, the coolant temperature should rise gradually to a normal operating range.

questions.question: The emergency air line:
questions.answerA: Is controlled by the foot brake.
questions.answerB: Is connected to the relay valves.
questions.answerC: Supplies air to the trailer air tanks.
