questions.explanation: The emergency air line (also known as the supply line) has two functions. The first is to supply air to the trailer air tanks on a combination vehicle, and the second is to control the emergency brakes.

questions.question: Look for matching colors when coupling glad hands. Service lines are often:
questions.answerB: Orange.
questions.answerC: Red.
questions.explanation: When coupling glad hands, make sure to couple together matching glad hands. To help drivers avoid mistakes, color coding is sometimes used. Service lines are often coded with the color blue and emergency lines are often coded with the color red.

questions.question: When the wheels of a trailer lock up:
questions.answerB: The trailer tends to swing around.
questions.answerC: The cab will swing, but the trailer will stay straight.
questions.explanation: A trailer may swing out and strike other vehicles if its wheels lock up. This is especially likely with lightly-loaded trailers.

questions.question: If confronted by an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to get out of their way.
questions.answerB: Avoid making eye contact.
questions.answerC: Ignore their hand gestures.
questions.explanation: If confronted by an aggressive driver, the most important thing to do is try to get out of their way. Avoid making eye contact with the driver and do not let yourself be provoked by gestures. Do not try to challenge aggressive drivers by speeding up.

questions.question: What can happen if one-fourth of the leaves in a leaf spring are missing when a vehicle is inspected?
questions.answerA: The vehicle’s driver will be allowed to drive, but only at reduced speeds.
questions.answerB: The vehicle will be put out-of-service until it is fixed.
questions.answerC: The vehicle will be fine to drive since most of the spring is in place.
questions.answerD: The driver will be asked to decrease the weight of the load.
questions.explanation: If at least one-fourth of the leaves in a leaf spring are missing, the vehicle will be put out-of-service until the defect is fixed.

questions.question: If you must drive very slowly, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive on the shoulder.
questions.answerC: Stay in the left lane.
questions.explanation: If you must drive slowly, you should warn drivers behind you by turning on your emergency flashers, as long as local law permits their use.

questions.question: To make your vehicle more visible during the day, you should:
questions.answerB: Use your high beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Use your clearance lights.
questions.explanation: Low beam headlights should be used for best visibility, even during the day. Using high beam headlights around other drivers can be dangerous.

questions.question: Carrying gases or liquids in a leaking tank is:
questions.answerB: Acceptable on shorter trips.
questions.answerC: Illegal.
questions.explanation: Before driving, be sure to check the tank's body for dents or cracks. You should also check around and under the vehicle for signs of leaks. It is a crime to carry gases or liquids in a leaking tank.

questions.question: Hydroplaning:
questions.answerB: Usually happens when vehicles are traveling faster than 65 mph.
questions.answerC: Can occur with a minimal amount of water on the roadway.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning is an effect in which a vehicle's tires lose traction with the surface of the road and instead glide along a layer of water. There does not have to be a large amount of water on the road for this to occur.

questions.question: You will often have to drive your vehicle under bridges and overpasses. If approaching such an opening, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume the posted clearance height is accurate.
questions.answerB: Assume the posted clearance height is inaccurate.
questions.answerC: Measure the height of the opening before proceeding.
questions.explanation: Do not assume that posted height clearances are accurate. If the road was repaved after the sign was posted, or if there is packed snow on the ground, the actual height of the opening may be different than what is indicated. If you are not confident that your vehicle will be able to safely clear an upcoming bridge or overpass, you should slow down and find another path, if possible.

questions.question: Load hazardous materials:
questions.answerB: Away from heat sources.
questions.answerC: In direct sunlight.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials should always be loaded away from heat sources. Many materials become more hazardous if their temperatures increase.

questions.question: In general, before loading or unloading any flammable liquids, an engine should be:
questions.answerB: Revved up.
questions.answerC: Turned on.
questions.explanation: Before loading or unloading a tank with flammable liquids, you should turn off the engine, unless running the engine is necessary to operate a pump. Ground the tank before opening the filling hole and maintain the ground until after closing the filling hole.

questions.question: Most heavy vehicles require ____ to change gears.
questions.answerB: Double shifting
questions.answerC: Triple clutching
questions.explanation: Most heavy vehicles with manual transmissions require double clutching to change gears. A driver should release the accelerator, push in the clutch, and shift into neutral at the same time. After releasing the clutch and allowing the vehicle to change to the necessary speed, the driver should push in the clutch, shift gears, then simultaneously release the clutch and accelerate.

questions.question: When traveling with Division 1.1 explosives, you may park no closer than ____ from the nearest building.
questions.answerB: 50 feet
questions.answerC: 300 feet
questions.explanation: When carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, you should not park within 300 feet of a bridge, tunnel, or building, unless you are parking for a short period of time while performing an operational necessity, like refueling.

questions.question: A vehicle inspection:
questions.answerB: Is helpful in identifying minor issues before they become major problems.
questions.answerC: Should not be done by the driver.
questions.answerD: Should be performed once a month.
questions.explanation: A vehicle should be inspected before every trip to help ensure that any small mechanical issues are caught before they become more serious problems. It is better to discover a problem with your vehicle before a drive than after the drive has begun.

questions.question: Shipping papers:
questions.answerA: Are not needed for most shipments.
questions.answerB: Are required for all shipments.
questions.answerC: Should be stored in a special compartment in the cab.
questions.answerD: Can be kept as a digital file.
questions.explanation: For all shipments of hazardous materials, the shipper must use shipping papers to inform drivers and dockworkers of the risks presented by the cargo.

questions.question: If a product requires a "Poison Inhalation Hazard" placard, the placard must be used when transporting:
questions.answerA: More than 100 pounds of the product.
questions.answerB: More than 50 pounds of the product.
questions.answerC: Any amount of the product.
questions.answerD: The product in a leaking container.
questions.explanation: For applicable materials, the "Poison Inhalation Hazard" placard and the appropriate hazard class placard must always be displayed, even for small amounts of the materials.

questions.question: If you are turning left at an intersection where there are two available turn lanes:
questions.answerA: It is best to use the right lane.
questions.answerB: It doesn’t matter which lane you use.
questions.answerC: It is best to use the left lane.
questions.explanation: You may have to swing right to safely make a left turn. If there are two left turn lanes available at an intersection, you should always begin your turn in the rightmost lane.

questions.question: A danger of a large truck swerving to avoid a hazard is:
questions.answerA: The truck may miss the object.
questions.answerB: The truck may flip over.
questions.answerC: The truck may stay in the same lane.
questions.answerD: Other vehicles may do the same thing.
questions.explanation: Swerving out of the way of a hazard is sometimes safer than trying to stop before reaching the hazard. You can usually turn away from something more quickly than you can come to a complete stop. However, swerving while in a vehicle that is either top-heavy or pulling multiple trailers may result in a rollover.

questions.question: When driving a tank:
questions.answerA: Curves should be taken faster than the posted speed limit.
questions.answerB: Curves should be taken more slowly than the posted speed limit.
questions.answerC: If there are two lanes of traffic, the tank should use both lanes.
questions.explanation: Tank vehicles have a high centers of gravity and are therefore particularly vulnerable to rollover. To lower this risk, tank vehicles should be driven well below the posted speed limit on curves.

questions.question: When driving on packed snow, you should reduce your speed:
questions.answerB: By about one-third.
questions.answerC: By about one-quarter.
questions.explanation: When driving on packed snow, you should reduce your speed by one-half or more. It can be difficult to stop or turn when operating on a slippery surface, so you must adjust your speed to drive safely under such conditions.

questions.question: If accepting a shipment, what could indicate that the cargo contains hazardous materials?
questions.answerA: The cargo is stored in cylinder tanks.
questions.answerB: The cargo is picked up from a supermarket.
questions.answerC: The cargo is packaged on wood pallets.
questions.explanation: Cylinders and drums are often used to contain hazardous materials. Be sure to take the proper precautions if transporting a cargo of hazardous materials.

questions.question: During a pre-trip inspection, what is the best method for checking your lights?
questions.answerA: Parking near a mirror to look for a reflection
questions.answerB: Activating the lights, then exiting the vehicle to check
questions.answerC: Looking on the instrument panel to see if any warning lights are illuminated
questions.answerD: Driving in traffic and waiting for other drivers to let you know your lights are out
questions.explanation: During a pre-trip inspection, you should activate your lights, then get out of the vehicle to look at them.

questions.question: The standee line is:
questions.answerA: A line that passengers must stand behind.
questions.answerB: A line that passengers must stand on.
questions.answerC: A line that should be used as passengers exit the bus.
questions.answerD: A line on the outside of a bus.
questions.explanation: On a bus designed to carry standing passengers, no passengers may stand in front of the rear of the driver's seat. Any such bus must have a line on the floor, or some other marking, that indicates where passengers may not stand. This is called a standee line.

questions.question: When driving under wet conditions, what does a lack of spray from other vehicles indicate?
questions.answerA: Ice has formed on the road.
questions.answerB: The pavement is dry.
questions.answerC: The spray is caught on the underside of the vehicle.
questions.answerD: The tires have soaked up all the moisture.
questions.explanation: If the road appears to be wet but the wheels of other vehicles are no longer generating spray, ice has formed on the road. Drive with extra caution when operating on wet or icy roads.

questions.question: When asked to make a turn while taking your driving test, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your turn signal, but only if other cars are present.
questions.answerB: Check traffic only in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerC: Check traffic in all directions.
questions.explanation: When asked to make a turn during the on-road driving test, you must check traffic in all directions and use your turn signal.

questions.question: When driving with passengers, a bus driver should:
questions.answerA: Engage in conversation with the passengers.
questions.answerB: Not engage in conversation with passengers.
questions.answerC: Ask passengers to watch out the windows for hazards.
questions.explanation: To avoid becoming distracted, a bus driver should not engage in conversation with passengers.

questions.question: During the driving test, when encountering a railroad crossing, you should:
questions.answerA: Pass another vehicle on the tracks if the other vehicle is going too slow.
questions.answerB: Get out of the vehicle to check for a train.
questions.answerC: Not change gears while your vehicle is on the tracks.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, do not stop, change gears, pass another vehicle, or change lanes while any part of your vehicle is in a railroad crossing.

questions.question: When are people usually the least alert?
questions.answerB: In the early evening
questions.answerC: Late at night
questions.explanation: Most drivers are the least alert at night, especially after midnight. Therefore, crashes due to fatigued driving are more likely at night than any other time of day.

questions.question: When changing lanes, you should:
questions.answerA: Move quickly, before other vehicles can enter into the lane.
questions.answerB: Move slowly in case another vehicle is in the lane.
questions.answerC: Not use a turn signal.
questions.explanation: Always change lanes slowly and smoothly. If there is a vehicle in the other lane that you did not see before beginning to move, they will have more time to react to your vehicle.

questions.question: A distracted driver:
questions.answerB: Usually has slowed perception.
questions.answerC: Is usually aware of what is happening around them.
questions.answerD: Is a good person to follow.
questions.explanation: Driving while distracted may result in slowed perception, delayed decision-making, and improper actions. Watch for distracted drivers and avoid them, when possible.

questions.question: A pre-trip inspection:
questions.answerA: Should be done in the same way every time.
questions.answerB: Should be done differently every time.
questions.answerC: Does not always need to include all items of concern.
questions.explanation: A pre-trip vehicle inspection should be done in the same way every time. Consistency will help a driver learn all of the proper steps and decrease the possibility of the driver forgetting to inspect something.

questions.question: The radiator cap:
questions.answerA: Should not be removed when the coolant is hot.
questions.answerB: Can be removed when the coolant is hot.
questions.answerC: Should be cool to the touch under normal driving conditions.
questions.explanation: Never remove the radiator cap or any part of the pressurized cooling system until it has cooled. Opening the cap while the system is too hot could release steam and boiling water that could severely burn you. If the radiator cap is cool to the touch, the system is likely cool enough for you to open the cap.

questions.question: Roads are especially slippery when it first begins to rain because:
questions.answerB: The fresh rain mixes with oil on the roadway.
questions.answerC: The water has nowhere to go.
questions.explanation: Roads are particularly slippery when it first begins to rain. The water mixes with oil drippings on the road that have not yet washed away, creating a slippery and dangerous mixture.

questions.question: When using your turn signal, you should:
questions.answerB: Turn the signal off before beginning the turn.
questions.answerC: Signal only if vehicles are in front of you.
questions.explanation: Always begin signaling well in advance of a turn. This is the best way to ensure that other drivers do not try to pass you. Without using a turn signal, drivers may assume that you are merely slowing down or stopping when you are planning to turn.

questions.question: When making a tight maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Not use your mirrors, as they can be distracting.
questions.answerB: Use your mirrors, but not too frequently.
questions.answerC: Use your mirrors frequently.
questions.explanation: It is important for you to be aware of your surroundings at all times. To do this, regularly check your mirrors. You should make a particular point of checking your mirrors when merging, changing lanes, turning, and performing tight maneuvers.

questions.question: If an approaching driver is using their high beam headlights, you should:
questions.answerB: Flash your high beam lights to remind the driver to switch to their low beams.
questions.answerC: Look to the right side of your lane until the vehicle has passed.
questions.answerD: Pull to the side of the road until the vehicle has passed.
questions.explanation: If a vehicle is coming toward you while using its high beam headlights, glance away from the headlights and toward the right side of the road until the vehicle has passed. This will keep you from being blinded by the lights.

questions.question: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) will:
questions.answerA: Allow you to drive faster than you would be able to otherwise.
questions.answerB: Allow you to follow other vehicles more closely than you would be able to otherwise.
questions.answerC: Allow you to drive less carefully than you would be able to otherwise.
questions.explanation: Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) will help you to maintain control during hard braking. ABS will not necessarily shorten your stopping distance.

questions.question: When checking your mirrors:
questions.answerA: The passenger side mirror should not be used.
questions.answerB: The driver's side mirror should not be used.
questions.answerC: Mirrors on both sides of the vehicle should be used.
questions.explanation: Regularly check mirrors on both sides of your vehicle while driving. It is important to be aware of what is happening behind and to the sides of your vehicle.

questions.question: When starting an engine, oil pressure should come up to a normal level:
questions.answerB: Within five minutes.
questions.answerC: After about three minutes.
questions.explanation: Look at your truck's gauges when starting the engine. The oil pressure in an engine should come up to a normal level within seconds of the vehicle's engine being started.

questions.question: The two indicators that determine when you should upshift are:
questions.answerB: Other trucks and road conditions.
questions.answerC: Timing and road position.
questions.answerD: Oil pressure and air brake pressure.
questions.explanation: There are two indicators that determine when you need to shift into a higher gear. One indicator is the engine speed (rpm). You should read your vehicle's manual to learn its rpm range and shift up when you reach the top of that range. The other indicator is road speed (mph). You should learn which speeds each gear can accommodate, then keep an eye on the speedometer and shift up as needed.

questions.question: When driving, it is important that you:
questions.answerA: Develop plans to get out of potentially dangerous situations.
questions.answerB: Enjoy the scenery.
questions.answerC: Turn your head all the way around rather than use mirrors.
questions.explanation: When driving, you should continually scan the road for possible hazards. Form plans about what you will do if the hazards develop into emergencies.

questions.question: To help your vehicle be seen by others:
questions.answerB: Your headlights should be turned off during the day.
questions.answerC: Your headlights should be covered with grease.
questions.answerD: Your headlights should be used, but only in the rain.
questions.explanation: A vehicle's headlights should be clean during trips. This will ensure that the lights can provide as much light as possible, helping the vehicle to be seen.

questions.question: When a vehicle is started, the coolant temperature should:
questions.answerB: Rise slowly.
questions.answerC: Hold steady.
questions.explanation: After an engine is started, the coolant temperature should begin a gradual rise toward the normal operating range.

questions.question: Looking far ahead of your vehicle while driving is:
questions.answerA: Discouraged, as there is little you can do about something far up the road.
questions.answerB: Encouraged to help you identify hazards as early as possible.
questions.answerC: Not permitted.
questions.explanation: Good drivers look down the road at least 12 to 15 seconds ahead of their vehicles. This makes it possible to identify hazards early, when drivers are more likely to have time to respond appropriately.

questions.question: The steering wheel should be:
questions.answerB: Held with one hand to keep the other hand free.
questions.answerC: Held with one hand at a time, alternating between hands.
questions.explanation: A steering wheel should be held firmly with both hands, placed on opposite sides of the wheel.

questions.question: Parking brakes:
questions.answerB: Should be tested, but only after driving a distance.
questions.answerC: Should be tested before a drive.
questions.answerD: Should be tested on a hill.
questions.explanation: Parking brakes should always be checked before driving as a part of your pre-trip inspection. If the parking brakes do not hold, the vehicle is faulty and should be fixed.

questions.question: When it is difficult to see and you are traveling near other drivers, you should:
questions.answerB: Use low beam lights.
questions.answerC: Use only the clearance lights.
questions.explanation: Use your low beam headlights when traveling near other drivers at times when it is difficult to see, such as at dawn, at dusk, or in poor weather conditions. Using the high beam setting under certain conditions could make it difficult for other drivers to see.

questions.question: When completing a conventional parallel parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Back up past the parking space, then pull forward into it.
questions.answerB: Pull forward past the parking space, then back into it.
questions.answerC: Pull forward directly into the parking space.
questions.explanation: You may be asked to complete a conventional parallel parking maneuver into a parking space that is to the right of your vehicle. You should drive past the parking space before backing into it while bringing the rear of your vehicle as close to the rear of the space as possible. Your vehicle should be completely within the boundaries of the space.

questions.question: Black ice is:
questions.answerA: A thick layer of ice on the road.
questions.answerB: A thin layer of ice on the road.
questions.answerC: Ice that is black from debris on the road.
questions.explanation: Black ice is a layer of ice that is thin and clear enough for the road to be visible through it. The surface will look like a wet road. Always be alert to black ice if the road looks wet when the temperature is below freezing.

questions.question: Compared to talking on a cell phone while driving, texting while driving is:
questions.answerB: Just as safe.
questions.answerC: More dangerous.
questions.explanation: Texting while driving is even more dangerous than speaking on a phone while driving. In addition to being mentally distracting, texting is also physically distracting.

questions.question: Steering wheel play should be no more than:
questions.answerB: 25 degrees.
questions.answerC: 50 degrees.
questions.explanation: Steering wheel play of more than 10 degrees (about two inches of movement at the rim of a 20-inch steering wheel) can make it difficult to steer.

questions.question: One way to prevent drowsiness while driving is to:
questions.answerB: Avoid regular exercise.
questions.answerC: Get adequate sleep the night before the trip.
questions.explanation: Driving while fatigued can be extremely dangerous. Strategies for preventing drowsiness while driving include getting a full night's sleep before a trip; having someone ride with you; scheduling trips for times during which you are normally awake; and avoiding medications that may cause drowsiness. Exercising regularly can increase your energy levels and make you less likely to become tired while driving.

questions.question: Be sure that your wheel bearing/seals are:
questions.answerB: Shiny.
questions.answerC: Rusted.
questions.explanation: During an inspection, ensure that the wheel bearing/seals are not leaking.

questions.question: If feeling sleepy while driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Press on and finish the trip.
questions.answerB: Drive faster to arrive to your destination sooner.
questions.answerC: Leave the road and take a nap.
questions.explanation: If you begin to feel sleepy while driving, the only safe response is to stop driving and get some sleep. Attempting to fight off exhaustion is dangerous and a major cause of fatal crashes. Stimulants are not a safe solution because they may help keep you awake but will not make you more alert. Once stimulants wear off, you will be even more tired than you were originally.

questions.question: When driving, it is important to:
questions.answerA: Avoid using your mirrors while in heavy traffic.
questions.answerB: Look only to the front and right side of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Look to the front, sides, and rear of the vehicle.
questions.explanation: It is essential that you are aware of what is happening on all sides of your vehicle at all times. Scan the road ahead and make regular checks of the mirrors on both sides of your vehicle while you are driving.

questions.question: A commercial motor vehicle should:
questions.answerA: Not be equipped with a fire extinguisher, unless transporting hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Not be equipped with a fire extinguisher, unless the vehicle will be traveling through remote areas.
questions.answerC: Never be equipped with a fire extinguisher.
questions.answerD: Always be equipped with at least one fire extinguisher.
questions.explanation: Vehicles must be equipped with the appropriate emergency equipment. When inspecting a CMV, you should check for at least one fire extinguisher; spare electrical fuses, unless the vehicle is equipped with circuit breakers; and the appropriate warning devices to be used when the vehicle is parked.

questions.question: A ramp's posted speed limit:
questions.answerB: Is suitable for some vehicles, but may be too fast for a large CMV.
questions.answerC: Is just a suggestion and may be exceeded.
questions.explanation: Posted speed limits on exit and entrance ramps often show speeds that are safe to be driven by cars. However, these speed limits may be too fast for large or heavily-loaded vehicles and CMV drivers will likely need to slow down to a speed below the posted limit.

questions.question: Carry-on baggage:
questions.answerA: May be left in the aisle.
questions.answerB: Must be secured away from exits.
questions.answerC: Should be placed near the doors.
questions.explanation: Bus passengers should not be allowed to leave baggage in any doorway or aisle. Baggage and freight must be secured in a manner that will prevent damage, allow the driver to move freely and easily, allow riders to exit by any window or door in an emergency, and protect riders from injury if the items fall or shift.

questions.question: When checking the exhaust system, it should be:
questions.answerB: Leaking.
questions.answerC: Fastened securely.
questions.explanation: When checking the exhaust system, you should verify that no parts of the system are loose, broken, or missing.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a sign of bad brake drums or shoes?
questions.answerB: Pads with oil on them
questions.answerC: Shoes worn thin
questions.answerD: Shoes that are not covered in brake fluid
questions.explanation: Potential problems to check for when inspecting brakes include cracked drums; shoes or pads with oil, grease, or brake fluid on them; and shoes that are missing, broken, or worn dangerously thin.

questions.question: How can you avoid becoming drowsy on a trip?
questions.answerA: Get about three hours of sleep beforehand.
questions.answerB: Plan ahead, including stopping points.
questions.answerC: Do not build exercise into your daily routine.
questions.explanation: Strategies to reduce the risk of fatigue while driving include getting seven to eight hours of sleep beforehand; scheduling trips for the hours during which you are normally awake; planning to take breaks during the trip; and exercising regularly.

questions.question: Parked delivery trucks may be hazardous because:
questions.answerB: People are often in a hurry when exiting such trucks and may not look for other vehicles.
questions.answerC: Packages often fall out of the trucks and into the road.
questions.explanation: Passing parked delivery or postal trucks can be dangerous because the driver may be in a hurry and pull into traffic without warning, or may they suddenly step out of the vehicle without checking for other traffic.

questions.question: What color is the low air pressure warning light?
questions.answerB: Orange
questions.answerC: Red
questions.explanation: A low air pressure warning signal is required in vehicles with air brakes. The warning light is usually red and may be accompanied by a buzzer.

questions.question: If you are driving and the ABS light comes on, it means that the ABS:
questions.answerA: Cannot work due to weather conditions.
questions.answerB: Has just been activated.
questions.answerC: Is not working properly.
questions.explanation: ABS malfunction lamps indicate that something in the Anti-Lock Braking System is not working properly.

questions.question: A dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Has a single air brake system, but uses two sets of controls.
questions.answerB: Has one air brake system for each side of the truck.
questions.answerC: Has two brakes for each wheel.
questions.answerD: Has two separate air brake systems, but uses a single set of controls.
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system has two separate air brake systems that use a single set of brake controls. One system typically operates the regular brakes on the rear axle or axles. The other system operates the regular brakes on the front axle.

questions.question: Some water and compressor oil is usually found in the compressed air within an air brake system. The water and compressor oil:
questions.answerA: Are necessary for the proper function of the system.
questions.answerB: Should take up about 10 percent of the tank.
questions.answerC: Should be removed regularly.
questions.explanation: If water and compressor oil are left to build up in an air brake system, the system can be damaged. Air storage tanks are equipped with drains to allow this accumulation to be removed. Manually controlled drains should be operated at the end of each day of driving.

questions.question: Foundation brakes are used:
questions.answerA: Only on the front wheels of a vehicle.
questions.answerB: Only on the rear wheels of a vehicle.
questions.answerC: On each wheel of a vehicle.
questions.explanation: Foundation brakes are used on each wheel of a CMV. The most common type of foundation brake is the s-cam drum brake.

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 must have:
questions.answerB: Bluetooth.
questions.answerC: A GPS.
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997, and other vehicles with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1998, must be equipped with anti-lock brakes.

questions.question: The ____ are activated by an electric switch that is triggered by the brake pedal.
questions.answerB: Turn signals
questions.answerC: Brake lights
questions.explanation: In a vehicle with air brakes, the brake lights are activated when the brake pedal is pushed and air pressure moves an electric switch. With the application of air pressure, the switch will then turn on the brake lights.

questions.question: If you are braking on dry pavement while traveling at 55 mph, how much distance will brake lag add to your overall stopping distance?
questions.answerB: 45 feet
questions.answerC: 20 feet
questions.explanation: The total stopping distance for vehicles equipped with air brakes is made up of four factors: perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. When braking at a speed of 55 mph while driving on dry pavement, the brake lag can add around 32 feet to the vehicle's total stopping distance.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Each system has separate air tanks, hoses, and lines.
questions.answerB: The systems share air tanks, but each has its own separate hoses and lines.
questions.answerC: Each system uses the same lines and hoses.
questions.answerD: One system is the main braking system and a second system is ready to be used if the first one fails.
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system is made up of two separate air brake systems. The systems share a single set of brake controls, but each has its own air tanks, hoses, and lines.

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Allow rain water to enter an air tank.
questions.answerB: Are used to drain water and oil from an air tank.
questions.answerC: Should never be opened.
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Manually operated air tank drains must be opened daily to remove this build-up.

questions.question: Using the brakes creates heat. If too much heat is produced:
questions.answerB: The brakes may squeak more than usual.
questions.answerC: The brakes will brake unevenly.
questions.explanation: Brakes are designed to take a lot of heat, but drivers should not rely solely on the brakes to slow their vehicle. Brakes may fade and lose their ability to slow down the vehicle if they become too hot, so drivers should also rely on the engine braking effect.

questions.question: Some air brake systems introduce alcohol into the system to:
questions.answerA: Make the brakes work without squeaking.
questions.answerB: Prevent ice from forming in the brake system.
questions.answerC: Prevent people from breathing the air from the system.
questions.explanation: Some air brake systems contain an alcohol evaporator. An evaporator introduces alcohol into the system to help inhibit the formation of ice in cold weather.

questions.question: While driving, ____ generally holds spring brakes in place.
questions.answerB: Electricity
questions.answerC: Gasoline
questions.explanation: While driving, spring brakes are generally held in place by air pressure. If the air pressure gets low enough, the springs will activate the brakes.

questions.question: When experiencing cold weather, be sure to check your vehicle's alcohol evaporator:
questions.answerB: Every day.
questions.answerC: Every other week.
questions.explanation: An alcohol evaporator can help prevent ice from building up in an air brake system. In cold weather, the evaporator should be checked and refilled every day.

questions.question: How is the parking brake released?
questions.answerA: By tapping the brake pedal three times
questions.answerB: By pushing in the brake control knob
questions.answerC: By starting the vehicle
questions.explanation: In vehicles with air brakes, the parking brake is controlled by a knob. The knob is pulled out to apply the brakes, and pushed in to release them.

questions.question: To confirm that a trailer has ABS, you can:
questions.answerA: Look under the trailer for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.
questions.answerB: Look under the hood for the ABS sticker.
questions.answerC: Look at the tires.
questions.answerD: Remove a tire and look for the ABS sensor on the axle.
questions.explanation: If you are unsure if a trailer is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), look under the vehicle for the electronic control unit and wheel speed sensor wires coming from the back of the brakes.

questions.question: In a vehicle with dual air brakes, a leak in one system ____ the second system.
questions.answerB: May not affect
questions.answerC: Is caused by
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system is made up of two separate air brake systems. If there is an air leak in one system, it may not affect the other.

questions.question: Front wheel braking works:
questions.answerB: Under all conditions.
questions.answerC: Only if the road is dry.
questions.explanation: Front wheel braking is effective under all road conditions. It is unlikely that you will experience a front wheel skid, even on ice.

questions.question: When you press the brake pedal in a vehicle with S-cam brakes, air pressure pushes out the rod and moves the:
questions.answerB: Axle.
questions.answerC: Brake drum.
questions.explanation: When pressing the brake pedal in a vehicle with S-cam brakes, air will enter the brake chambers. The added air pressure will push out the rods and move slack adjusters, twisting the brake camshafts.

questions.question: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you must wait for the air compressor to build a minimum of ____ in both the primary and secondary systems.
questions.answerB: 50 psi
questions.answerC: 75 psi
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you should wait for the air compressor to build up at least 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems.

questions.question: The leakage rate for a triple combination vehicle with air brakes should be no more than ____ in one minute during a static leakage test.
questions.answerB: 5 psi
questions.answerC: 3 psi
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a triple combination vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 5 psi in one minute. If the air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: Air brakes use ____ to function.
questions.answerB: Liquid air
questions.answerC: Nitrogen
questions.explanation: Air brakes function through the use of compressed air.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a part of an air brake system?
questions.answerB: A parking brake system
questions.answerC: An emergency brake system
questions.explanation: Air brakes consists of three separate braking systems: the service brake system, the parking brake system, and the emergency brake system.

questions.question: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, once air pressure is lost and the spring brakes come on:
questions.answerA: You will be unable to move the vehicle.
questions.answerB: A separate air tank can be used to release the spring brakes for a short period of time.
questions.answerC: You can use the spring brakes to continue driving normally.
questions.answerD: The air tanks will automatically refill to a safe air pressure level.
questions.explanation: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, there is a separate air tank that can be used to temporarily release the spring brakes if they have been activated due to low air pressure. Pushing in the proper control will release the spring brakes for a short period of time, allowing the driver to move the vehicle in an emergency.

questions.question: ____ make up the emergency brake system.
questions.answerA: Only parts of the parking brake system
questions.answerB: Only parts of the service brake system
questions.answerC: Parts of the parking and service brake systems
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, there are three different braking systems: a service brake system, a parking brake system, and an emergency brake system. The emergency brake system uses parts of both the parking and service brake systems.

questions.question: How many air storage tanks are used in an air brake system?
questions.answerB: Four tanks
questions.answerC: Six tanks
questions.explanation: Air storage tanks are used to hold compressed air. The number and size of air tanks in an air brake system varies among vehicles.

questions.question: Most heavy-duty vehicles use ____ air brake systems.
questions.answerB: Dual
questions.answerC: Triple
questions.explanation: The majority of heavy-duty vehicles are equipped with dual air brake systems.

questions.question: All air tanks must include:
questions.answerB: A lock.
questions.answerC: A trap door.
questions.explanation: Air brake system tanks must contain drain valves. These valves are used to drain accumulated oil and water from the tanks and may be either manually or automatically operated.

questions.question: What is brake lag?
questions.answerA: The time required for the brakes to work after the brake pedal is pushed
questions.answerB: The distance between the brake pedal’s resting position and the floor
questions.answerC: The amount of air pressure used to stop a vehicle
questions.explanation: Because air takes time to flow through the air lines to the brakes, air brakes cannot begin working instantly. There is often a brake lag of at least one-half of a second between the moment the brake pedal is pressed and the moment the brakes begin to work. On vehicles with hydraulic brakes, the brakes work instantly when the pedal is pressed.

questions.question: Most heavy-duty vehicles use:
questions.answerB: Dual air brake systems.
questions.answerC: Triple air brake systems.
questions.explanation: Most heavy-duty vehicles use dual air brake systems, in which there are two separate braking systems operated by a single set of controls. Each system operates the brakes on different axles.

questions.question: To stop a vehicle using air brakes:
questions.answerA: The brake pedal should be pressed.
questions.answerB: The brake pedal should be lifted.
questions.answerC: The brake knob should be pulled out.
questions.answerD: The brake knob should be pushed in.
questions.explanation: To stop normally in a vehicle with air brakes, press down the brake pedal.

questions.question: What should happen before the air pressure in an air brake system tank falls below 55 psi?
questions.answerB: The vehicle will be unable to shift out of gear.
questions.answerC: The front lights should flash.
questions.explanation: The low air pressure warning signal must activate before the air supply pressure drops below 55 psi in the air tank. If the warning signal does not turn on when being tested during an inspection, the vehicle is not safe to drive.

questions.question: Why do large vehicles use air brakes?
questions.answerA: Other brake systems squeak too loudly.
questions.answerB: Air braking systems are very effective.
questions.answerC: Air brakes are complicated.
questions.explanation: Air brakes are an effective and safe way of stopping large and heavy vehicles, as long as they are maintained and used properly.

questions.question: Failing to drain air tanks could result in:
questions.answerA: Water accumulations freezing and causing brake failure.
questions.answerB: Squishy brakes.
questions.answerC: Too much air collecting in the tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air tanks must be periodically drained to remove accumulations of water and compressor oil. If water is not removed, it could freeze in cold weather and cause brake failure.

questions.question: ____ make up the emergency brake system.
questions.answerA: Only parts of the parking brake system
questions.answerB: Only parts of the service brake system
questions.answerC: Parts of the parking and service brake systems
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, there are three different braking systems: a service brake system, a parking brake system, and an emergency brake system. The emergency brake system uses parts of both the parking and service brake systems.

questions.question: Foundation brakes are used:
questions.answerB: Only at the rear wheels.
questions.answerC: Only at the driver’s side wheels.
questions.explanation: Foundation brakes are used at each wheel. The most common type is the S-cam drum brake.

questions.question: Using an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerB: Shortens brake response time.
questions.answerC: Provides less control.
questions.explanation: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) helps prevent wheel lockup during hard braking. While it provides better control, it does not necessarily shorten a vehicle's stopping distance.

questions.question: Brakes can get out of adjustment:
questions.answerB: During the winter.
questions.answerC: If they are used at all.
questions.answerD: If brakes on one side are used more often than brakes on the other side.
questions.explanation: Brakes are particularly prone to getting out out adjustment if they are hot. Use proper braking techniques to avoid letting your brakes overheat.

questions.question: What is removed when an air tank is drained?
questions.answerB: Ammonia
questions.answerC: Wood
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks are equipped with drains to allow water and compressor oil to be removed. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system.

questions.question: Why should you regularly drain the air tanks?
questions.answerA: Because the air gets old and needs to be replaced
questions.answerB: Because compressed air contains some water and the water collects in the tanks
questions.answerC: To allow for a change in pressure
questions.explanation: Compressed air usually contains a certain amount of moisture and compressor oil, which can build up in the air storage tanks and damage the brake system. The tanks should be drained to clean out these accumulations. On a tank with a manual drain valve, draining should be performed at the end of each day of driving.

questions.question: If the low air pressure warning signal comes on, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue driving, but have the brakes repaired within a week.
questions.answerB: Pull over and inspect the brakes.
questions.answerC: Phone a mechanic while driving.
questions.explanation: If the low air pressure warning signal comes on while you are driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should immediately bring the vehicle to a safe stop while you are still able to control the brakes. Inspect and repair the brakes as soon as possible.

questions.question: Air tank drains should:
questions.answerA: Not be used by the driver.
questions.answerB: Only be used when it is wet outside.
questions.answerC: Be used to drain the tanks completely.
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Manually operated air tank drains must be opened daily to remove this build-up.

questions.question: A ____ allows a driver to gradually apply spring brakes.
questions.answerB: Trailer air supply control
questions.answerC: Relay valve
questions.explanation: A modulating control valve allows a driver to gradually apply spring brakes. In equipped vehicles, the valve is controlled by a lever located on the dashboard.

questions.question: What kind of force do emergency brakes use?
questions.answerB: Mechanical
questions.answerC: Heavy
questions.explanation: Air brakes are really three different braking systems: the service brake, the parking brake, and the emergency brake. Emergency and parking brakes are applied with mechanical force.

questions.question: An air compressor governor will stop the compressor from pumping air once the air tanks have an air pressure level of:
questions.answerB: 100 psi.
questions.answerC: 150 psi.
questions.explanation: An air compressor governor will stop the compressor from pumping air once the air tanks are at an air pressure level of 125 psi. This air pressure level is referred to as the "cut-out" level.

questions.question: A safety valve is set to open at ____ pounds per square inch (psi).
questions.explanation: The safety valve protects air tanks and the rest of an air brake system from accumulating too much air pressure. The safety valve is usually set to open at 150 psi.

questions.question: If you are braking on dry pavement while traveling at 55 mph, how much distance will brake lag add to your overall stopping distance?
questions.answerB: 45 feet
questions.answerC: 20 feet
questions.explanation: The total stopping distance for vehicles equipped with air brakes is made up of four factors: perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. When braking at a speed of 55 mph while driving on dry pavement, the brake lag can add around 32 feet to the vehicle's total stopping distance.

questions.question: Brakes may get out of adjustment:
questions.answerB: In colder weather.
questions.answerC: If they are used.
questions.explanation: Brakes can get out of adjustment quickly, especially if they are used to the point of overheating. Brake adjustment should be checked frequently.

questions.question: What do air brakes use to make the brakes work?
questions.answerB: Outside air
questions.answerC: Non-compressed air
questions.explanation: Many large CMVs are equipped with air brakes. An air braking system uses compressed air to operate.

questions.question: An emergency brake must be controlled by:
questions.answerB: Air pressure.
questions.answerC: Gravity.
questions.explanation: All trucks, truck tractors, and buses must be equipped with emergency brakes and parking brakes. Because air pressure can eventually leak away, emergency and parking brakes should be held on by mechanical force.

questions.question: When backing a trailer, you must turn the steering wheel:
questions.answerA: In the direction you want the trailer to move.
questions.answerB: In the direction opposite of where you want the trailer to move.
questions.answerC: To the left until backing is complete.
questions.explanation: When backing a vehicle with a trailer, you must turn the steering wheel in the direction opposite of where you want to go. Once your trailer starts to turn, you should turn the steering wheel the other way to follow the trailer.

questions.question: In a vehicle equipped with an automatic tractor protection valve, the valve will pop out when air pressure drops to a level between:
questions.answerB: 75 and 105 psi.
questions.answerC: 50 and 65 psi.
questions.explanation: In vehicles equipped with an automatic tractor protection valve, the valve will pop out if air pressure drops to a level between 20 and 45 psi. When the valve pops out, the protection valve will close, stopping the flow of air.

questions.question: An air supply control in its "emergency" position will:
questions.answerB: Apply the trailer emergency brakes.
questions.answerC: Prevent a skid.
questions.explanation: Tractor protection controls in older vehicles may be operated by levers instead of knobs. If an air supply control is set in its "emergency" position, the air supply will be stopped and the trailer emergency brakes will be applied.

questions.question: Fully-loaded rigs:
questions.answerA: Are less likely to roll over than empty rigs.
questions.answerB: Are more likely to roll over than empty rigs.
questions.answerC: Are just as likely to roll over as empty rigs.
questions.explanation: Because the weight of cargo gives them a higher center of gravity, fully-loaded rigs are 10 times more likely to roll over in a crash than empty rigs.

questions.question: Simply changing lanes can cause:
questions.answerA: A “crack-the-whip” effect, resulting in a rollover.
questions.answerB: A trailer to straighten out.
questions.answerC: Confusion over which lane the driver is hoping to use.
questions.answerD: Other drivers to reduce their speed.
questions.explanation: Due to the "crack-the-whip" effect caused by rearward amplification, changing lanes too quickly in a combination vehicle can result in a rollover.

questions.question: More than half of all accident-related truck driver deaths are caused by:
questions.answerB: Slippery roads.
questions.answerC: Other drivers.
questions.explanation: More than half of all accident-related truck driver deaths are a result of truck rollovers. To help prevent a rollover, be sure to load cargo low to the ground and centered on your rig. Take corners slowly and carefully.

questions.question: When driving a vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), brakes should be applied:
questions.answerA: In the same way as they would be in a vehicle without ABS.
questions.answerB: As the vehicle is placed in neutral.
questions.answerC: With the hand brake.
questions.explanation: When driving a vehicle with ABS, you should brake in the same manner as you would in a vehicle without ABS.

questions.question: Watching the road ahead:
questions.answerA: Is more dangerous than only watching your mirrors.
questions.answerB: Does not help you drive more safely.
questions.answerC: Can help you avoid the need for sudden lane changes.
questions.explanation: Making a sudden lane change can be dangerous while driving a combination vehicle. You can avoid the need to make a sudden lange change by looking down the road for upcoming obstacles that will require you to change lanes.

questions.question: Which of the following types of vehicles is most prone to the “crack-the-whip" effect?
questions.answerB: A three-axle tractor
questions.answerC: A bobtail tractor
questions.explanation: Double and triple combinations are the most vulnerable to turning over as a result of the "crack-the-whip" effect.

questions.question: What can the “crack-the-whip” effect do?
questions.answerB: Make loud noises.
questions.answerC: Make trucks accelerate.
questions.explanation: The "crack-the-whip" effect can cause a trailer to turn over during a lane change. To avoid this phenomenon, drivers should make lane changes at slow, safe speeds.

questions.question: To help prevent a rollover, cargo should be:
questions.answerA: Placed as high as possible inside the trailer.
questions.answerB: Placed as low as possible inside the trailer.
questions.answerC: Placed on the passenger side of the trailer.
questions.answerD: Placed on the driver’s side of the trailer.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a rollover, the weight of cargo in a trailer should be kept as low to the ground as possible. Weight should not be placed primarily on one side of the trailer as this could make the trailer lean, increasing the risk of a rollover.

questions.question: Combination vehicles:
questions.answerA: Often have taller trailers than single commercial vehicles.
questions.answerB: Are usually lighter than single commercial vehicles.
questions.answerC: Require more skill to drive than single commercial vehicles.
questions.explanation: Driving combination vehicles requires more skill than driving single commercial vehicles. Combinations are generally longer, generally heavier, and are more vulnerable to rollover.

questions.question: To prevent a rollover, a driver should:
questions.answerB: Place cargo high.
questions.answerC: Keep cargo loose.
questions.explanation: Rollovers can happen when a combination vehicle is turned too quickly. To help prevent the risk of rollover, it is important to keep the vehicle's center of gravity low by loading cargo as close to the ground as possible.

questions.question: What is another name for the service line?
questions.answerB: Exchange line
questions.answerC: Surplus line
questions.explanation: The service line, also called the control line or signal line, carries air to the trailer brakes and is controlled by the foot brake or trailer hand brake.

questions.question: Push in the trailer air supply control to:
questions.answerB: Deactivate the air brakes.
questions.answerC: Sound the horn.
questions.explanation: Push in the trailer air supply control to supply the trailer with air. Pull out the trailer air supply control to turn off the air supply and activate the emergency brakes.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve:
questions.answerA: Should always be used for parking.
questions.answerB: Should only be used for parking on a downhill.
questions.answerC: Should never be used for parking.
questions.answerD: Should only be used when transporting cargo.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve should not be used for parking. This could cause all of the air to leak out of the braking system, resulting in the brakes releasing. Instead, use the parking brake.

questions.question: If the emergency air line loses pressure:
questions.answerA: The Anti-Lock Braking System will activate.
questions.answerB: The service air line will activate.
questions.answerC: The emergency brakes will activate.
questions.explanation: The emergency air line controls the emergency brakes on a combination vehicle. A loss of air pressure in the emergency line will cause the emergency trailer brakes to activate.

questions.question: The emergency air line:
questions.answerA: Is controlled by the foot brake.
questions.answerB: Is connected to the relay valves.
questions.answerC: Supplies air to the trailer air tanks.
questions.explanation: The emergency air line (also known as the supply line) has two functions. The first is to supply air to the trailer air tanks on a combination vehicle, and the second is to control the emergency brakes.

questions.question: During a trip, which shut-off valves should be open?
questions.answerA: All shut-off valves should be open.
questions.answerB: The rear shut-off valves should be open.
questions.answerC: All shut-off valves should be in the open position, except the rear shut-off valves.
questions.answerD: No shut-off valves should be open.
questions.explanation: When starting a trip, be sure that all shut-off valves are in the open position, except for the last valves on the rear trailer. It is important that air reaches the brakes on all trailers and that the air is not able to escape from the back of the vehicle.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve should:
questions.answerB: Be used only to test the trailer brakes.
questions.answerC: Be used together with the brake pedal.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve works the trailer brakes but should only be used when testing them. Using it while driving could create a skid. Never use the trailer hand valve while parking because doing so may release the air pressure from the braking system, releasing the brakes that are holding the vehicle in place.

questions.question: An air supply control lever should be in its "normal" position when you are:
questions.answerB: Applying the trailer emergency brakes.
questions.answerC: Pulling a trailer.
questions.explanation: Tractor protection controls in older vehicles may be operated by levers instead of knobs. If an air supply control is set in its "normal" position, it is properly set for you to pull a trailer.

questions.question: Older trailers are not equipped with spring brakes. This means that if the air supply for a vehicle's air braking system leaks away:
questions.answerB: The trailer will not have brakes.
questions.answerC: The trailer will speed up.
questions.explanation: Older trailers do not have spring brakes. This means that if the air supply in an older trailer's air tank has leaked away, there will be no working brakes connected to the trailer and its wheels will turn freely.

questions.question: In a double or triple combination:
questions.answerA: Cargo weight must be evenly distributed between all trailers.
questions.answerB: The heaviest trailer should be positioned directly behind the cab.
questions.answerC: The heaviest trailer should be positioned in the rear.
questions.answerD: The weight of the trailers does not matter.
questions.explanation: When positioning trailers in a combination, the most heavily-loaded trailer should be the closest to the tractor. The lightest trailer should be positioned in the rear.

questions.question: To prevent a rollover, cargo should be:
questions.answerA: Placed near the front of a trailer.
questions.answerB: Placed near the rear of a trailer.
questions.answerC: Spread out on a trailer.
questions.answerD: Loaded with most weight on the driver’s side of a trailer.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of rollover, the weight of cargo in a trailer should be centered and spread out as much as possible. The weight of the cargo should also be kept as low to the ground as possible.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve should:
questions.answerB: Be used only to test the trailer brakes.
questions.answerC: Be used together with the brake pedal.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve works the trailer brakes but should only be used when testing them. Using it while driving could create a skid. Never use the trailer hand valve while parking because doing so may release the air pressure from the braking system, releasing the brakes that are holding the vehicle in place.

questions.question: Watching the road ahead:
questions.answerA: Is more dangerous than only watching your mirrors.
questions.answerB: Does not help you drive more safely.
questions.answerC: Can help you avoid the need for sudden lane changes.
questions.explanation: Making a sudden lane change can be dangerous while driving a combination vehicle. You can avoid the need to make a sudden lange change by looking down the road for upcoming obstacles that will require you to change lanes.

questions.question: What is a bobtail tractor?
questions.answerB: A tractor with two semi-trailers
questions.answerC: A tractor that travels faster than the speed limit
questions.explanation: Tractors without semi-trailers are referred to as "bobtail tractors." Bobtail tractors are difficult to operate and drivers must exercise caution.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve should be used:
questions.answerA: Regularly to activate the trailer brakes in all driving conditions.
questions.answerB: Only to test the trailer brakes.
questions.answerC: Only in inclement weather when the trailer may skid.
questions.answerD: Only if the trailer is carrying a load.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve should be used only to test the trailer brakes. It should not be used while driving because it may cause the trailer to skid.

questions.question: If you are operating a vehicle built before 1998 and are unsure if the trailer has an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you can:
questions.answerA: Check for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.
questions.answerB: Look for a red light on the front right corner of the converter dolly.
questions.answerC: Pump the air brakes to activate the ABS.
questions.explanation: If you are operating a vehicle built before 1998 and are unsure if the trailer has an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you can check under the trailer for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.

questions.question: When a vehicle goes around a corner, the rear wheels:
questions.answerA: Follow the same path as the front wheels.
questions.answerB: Follow a different path than the front wheels.
questions.answerC: Should not be a concern to the driver.
questions.explanation: When any vehicle goes around a corner, the rear wheels follow a different path than the front wheels. This is called off-tracking. The degree of off-tracking will be greater on long vehicles than on short vehicles.

questions.question: To find out if a vehicle that was built before 1998 has an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you can:
questions.answerA: Pump the air brakes to activate the ABS.
questions.answerB: Look into the back of the fifth wheel.
questions.answerC: Check for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.
questions.explanation: If you are operating a vehicle built before 1998 and are unsure if the trailer has an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you can check under the trailer for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.

questions.question: If a load is placed on one side of a trailer, the trailer:
questions.answerA: May lean, and could result in a rollover.
questions.answerB: May add extra support during turns.
questions.answerC: Have improved braking.
questions.explanation: If the weight of a load is placed primarily one side of a trailer, the trailer may lean, increasing the risk of a rollover.

questions.question: What can the “crack-the-whip” effect do?
questions.answerB: Make loud noises.
questions.answerC: Make trucks accelerate.
questions.explanation: The "crack-the-whip" effect can cause a trailer to turn over during a lane change. To avoid this phenomenon, drivers should make lane changes at slow, safe speeds.

questions.question: When connecting a converter dolly to a second trailer, the trailer height should be ____ the center of the fifth wheel.
questions.answerB: Slightly higher than
questions.answerC: Slightly lower than
questions.explanation: When connecting a converter dolly to a second or third trailer, the trailer height should correct. It should be slightly lower than the center of the fifth wheel.

questions.question: When braking while pulling a trailer equipped with anti-lock brakes, you should:
questions.answerB: Use extra braking force to ensure the brakes kick in.
questions.answerC: Brake as you would without anti-lock brakes.
questions.explanation: When driving a tractor-trailer combination that is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should brake in the same manner that you would if the vehicle was not equipped with ABS.

questions.question: Rearward amplification refers to:
questions.answerA: The amount of noise projected to the rear of a vehicle.
questions.answerB: The cause of the "crack-the-whip" effect.
questions.answerC: The number of trailers that can be pulled by a tractor.
questions.explanation: Vehicles with trailers are vulnerable to rollover due to the "crack-the-whip" effect, which is caused by rearward amplification.

questions.question: In a double or triple combination, the ____ trailer should be directly behind the cab.
questions.answerB: Heaviest
questions.answerC: Smallest
questions.explanation: When positioning trailers in a combination, the most heavily-loaded trailer should be the closest to the tractor. The lightest trailer should be positioned in the rear.

questions.question: Bobtail tractors are ____ to stop than tractors attached to full semitrailers.
questions.answerB: Easier
questions.answerC: More difficult
questions.explanation: Bobtail tractors are tractors that are not attached to any semitrailers. When operating a bobtail, you should be aware that stopping can be difficult and that it will take a longer distance to come to a complete stop than a tractor attached to a loaded semitrailer.

questions.question: Before a drive, ensure that air flows to all trailers by:
questions.answerA: Opening the rear shut-off valves and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerB: Closing the rear shut-off valves and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerC: Disconnecting air supply lines and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerD: Rolling each trailer down a hill and testing the brakes.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, ensure that air in the air brake system reaches all trailers. Do this by waiting for air pressure to build, then sending air to both the emergency and service lines and opening the shut-off valves on the rear of the last trailer. If air escapes from the shut-off valves in the rear of the combination, the air is being supplied to the entire vehicle.

questions.question: A trolley valve:
questions.answerB: Should only be used to test trailer brakes.
questions.answerC: Should be used when parking uphill.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve (also referred to as the trolley valve or Johnson bar) is a mechanism that works the trailer brakes. It should only be used to test the brakes. Using it while the vehicle is being driven could cause a skid. Never use the trailer hand valve while parking because doing so may release the air pressure  from the braking system, releasing the brakes that are holding the vehicle in place.
